[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7mlines 1193-1257/1257 (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:17:51]# man journalctl -b 0 10[Kman journalctl
[?1049h[?1h=JOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[m
       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
       entry collected.[m
[m
       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[m
       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[m
       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[m
       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[m
       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[m
       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[m
       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[m
       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[m
           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kff[Kaa[Kcc[Kii[Kll[Kii[Ktt[Kyy[K[1;1HJOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
[11;1H       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
[14;1H       entry collected.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
[17;1H       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
[18;1H       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
[19;1H       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
[20;1H       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
[21;1H       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
[22;1H       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
[23;1H       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
[24;1H       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
[27;1H       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
[28;1H       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
[29;1H       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
[30;1H       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
[31;1H       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
[32;1H       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
[35;1H       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
[38;1H       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
[41;1H       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
[44;1H       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
[45;1H       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
[46;1H       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
[47;1H       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
[50;1H       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
[51;1H       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
[54;1H       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[57;1H       The following options are understood:[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
[60;1H           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
[61;1H           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[66;1H[1;1HJOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
[11;1H       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
[14;1H       entry collected.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
[17;1H       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
[18;1H       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
[19;1H       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
[20;1H       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
[21;1H       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
[22;1H       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
[23;1H       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
[24;1H       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
[27;1H       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
[28;1H       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
[29;1H       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
[30;1H       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
[31;1H       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
[32;1H       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
[35;1H       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
[38;1H       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
[41;1H       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
[44;1H       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
[45;1H       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
[46;1H       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
[47;1H       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
[50;1H       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
[51;1H       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
[54;1H       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[57;1H       The following options are understood:[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
[60;1H           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
[61;1H           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
           the journal.[m
[m
       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[m
       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[m
       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[m
           [1mshort[0m[m
               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[m
           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[m
           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mverbose[0m[m
               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[m
           [1mexport[0m[m
               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[m
           [1mjson[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
               information).[m
[m
           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
               more readable by humans.[m
[m
           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[m
           [1mcat[0m[m
               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[m
       [1m--utc[0m[m
           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 68/386 34% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kcc[Krr[Koo[Knn[K[1;1H           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
[4;1H           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
[5;1H           the journal.[m
[6;1H[m
[7;1H       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
[8;1H           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
[9;1H           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
[10;1H           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
[11;1H           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
[14;1H           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
[15;1H           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
[16;1H           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
[19;1H           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
[22;1H           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
[25;1H           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H           [1mshort[0m[m
[28;1H               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
[29;1H               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[30;1H[m
[31;1H           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
[32;1H               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
[35;1H               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
[38;1H               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H           [1mverbose[0m[m
[41;1H               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H           [1mexport[0m[m
[44;1H               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
[45;1H               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[46;1H[m
[47;1H           [1mjson[0m[m
[48;1H               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
[49;1H               information).[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
[52;1H               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
[53;1H               more readable by humans.[m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
[56;1H               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
[57;1H               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H           [1mcat[0m[m
[60;1H               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
[61;1H               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1m--utc[0m[m
[64;1H           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1H           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
[4;1H           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
[5;1H           the journal.[m
[6;1H[m
[7;1H       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
[8;1H           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
[9;1H           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
[10;1H           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
[11;1H           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
[14;1H           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
[15;1H           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
[16;1H           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
[19;1H           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
[22;1H           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[23;1H[m

[63;1H       [1m--utc[0m[m
[64;1H           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H...skipping...
           [7mlevel[27m (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log [7mlevel[27ms in the form[m
           FROM..TO. The log [7mlevel[27ms are the usual syslog log [7mlevel[27ms as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m
           "emerg" (0), "alert" (1), "crit" (2), "err" (3), "warning" (4), "notice" (5), "info" (6),[m
           "debug" (7). If a single log [7mlevel[27m is specified, all messages with this log [7mlevel[27m or a lower (hence[m
           more important) log [7mlevel[27m are shown. If a range is specified, all messages within the range are[m
           shown, including both the start and the end value of the range. This will add "PRIORITY=" matches for[m
           the specified priorities.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m, [1m--cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal specified by the passed cursor.[m
[m
       [1m--after-cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal [4mafter[24m the location specified by the this[m
           cursor. The cursor is shown when the [1m--show-cursor[0m option is used.[m
[m
       [1m--show-cursor[0m[m
           The cursor is shown after the last entry after two dashes:[m
[m
               -- cursor: s=0639...[m
[m
           The format of the cursor is private and subject to change.[m
[m
       [1m-S[0m, [1m--since=[0m, [1m-U[0m, [1m--until=[0m[m
           Start showing entries on or newer than the specified date, or on or older than the specified date,[m
           respectively. Date specifications should be of the format "2012-10-30 18:17:16". If the time part is[m
           omitted, "00:00:00" is assumed. If only the seconds component is omitted, ":00" is assumed. If the[m
           date component is omitted, the current day is assumed. Alternatively the strings "yesterday",[m
           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
           after the current time, respectively.[m
[m
       [1m-F[0m, [1m--field=[0m[m
           Print all possible data values the specified field can take in all entries of the journal.[m
[m
       [1m--system[0m, [1m--user[0m[m
           Show messages from system services and the kernel (with [1m--system[0m). Show messages from service of[m
           current user (with [1m--user[0m). If neither is specified, show all messages that the user can see.[m
[m
       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
           Show messages from a running, local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[m
       [1m-D[0m [4mDIR[24m, [1m--directory=[0m[4mDIR[24m[m
           Takes a directory path as argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           directory [4mDIR[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths.[m
[m
       [1m--file=[0m[4mGLOB[24m[m
           Takes a file glob as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           files matching [4mGLOB[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths. May be specified[m
           multiple times, in which case files will be suitably interleaved.[m
[m
       [1m--root=[0m[4mROOT[24m[m
           Takes a directory path as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on catalog file[m
           hierarchy underneath the specified directory instead of the root directory (e.g.  [1m--update-catalog[0m[m
           will create [4mROOT[24m/var/lib/systemd/catalog/database).[m
[m
       [1m--new-id128[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, generate a new 128-bit ID suitable for identifying messages.[m
           This is intended for usage by developers who need a new identifier for a new message they introduce[m
           and want to make recognizable. This will print the new ID in three different formats which can be[m
           copied into source code or similar.[m
[m
       [1m--header[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, show internal header information of the journal fields accessed.[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 190/386 70% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m

[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 180/386 68% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 179/386 68% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 178/386 67% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 177/386 66% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m

[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 161/386 62% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[KSS[K[KFF[KAA[KCC[KII[K[1;1H           If the 32-character [4mID[24m is specified, it may optionally be followed by [4moffset[24m which identifies the[m
[2;1H           boot relative to the one given by boot [4mID[24m. Negative values mean earlier boots and a positive values[m
[3;1H           mean later boots. If [4moffset[24m is not specified, a value of zero is assumed, and the logs for the boot[m
[4;1H           given by [4mID[24m are shown.[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       [1m--list-boots[0m[m
[7;1H           Show a tabular list of boot numbers (relative to the current boot), their IDs, and the timestamps of[m
[8;1H           the first and last message pertaining to the boot.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       [1m-k[0m, [1m--dmesg[0m[m
[11;1H           Show only kernel messages. This implies [1m-b[0m and adds the match "_TRANSPORT=kernel".[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1m-t[0m, [1m--identifier=[0m[4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
[14;1H           Show messages for the specified syslog identifier [4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m, or for any of the messages with[m
[15;1H           a "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER" matched by [4mPATTERN[24m.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
[20;1H           Show messages for the specified systemd unit [4mUNIT[24m (such as a service unit), or for any of the units[m
[21;1H           matched by [4mPATTERN[24m. If a pattern is specified, a list of unit names found in the journal is compared[m
[22;1H           with the specified pattern and all that match are used. For each unit name, a match is added for[m
[23;1H           messages from the unit ("_SYSTEMD_UNIT=[4mUNIT[24m"), along with additional matches for messages from[m
[24;1H           systemd and messages about coredumps for the specified unit.[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[27;1H[m
[28;1H       [1m-p[0m, [1m--priority=[0m[m
[29;1H           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m
[30;1H           level (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log levels in the form[m
[31;1H           FROM..TO. The log levels are the usual syslog log levels as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m
[32;1H           "emerg" (0), "alert" (1), "crit" (2), "err" (3), "warning" (4), "notice" (5), "info" (6),[m
[33;1H           "debug" (7). If a single log level is specified, all messages with this log level or a lower (hence[m
[34;1H           more important) log level are shown. If a range is specified, all messages within the range are[m
[35;1H           shown, including both the start and the end value of the range. This will add "PRIORITY=" matches for[m
[36;1H           the specified priorities.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       [1m-c[0m, [1m--cursor=[0m[m
[39;1H           Start showing entries from the location in the journal specified by the passed cursor.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H       [1m--after-cursor=[0m[m
[42;1H           Start showing entries from the location in the journal [4mafter[24m the location specified by the this[m
[43;1H           cursor. The cursor is shown when the [1m--show-cursor[0m option is used.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H       [1m--show-cursor[0m[m
[46;1H           The cursor is shown after the last entry after two dashes:[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               -- cursor: s=0639...[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H           The format of the cursor is private and subject to change.[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H       [1m-S[0m, [1m--since=[0m, [1m-U[0m, [1m--until=[0m[m
[53;1H           Start showing entries on or newer than the specified date, or on or older than the specified date,[m
[54;1H           respectively. Date specifications should be of the format "2012-10-30 18:17:16". If the time part is[m
[55;1H           omitted, "00:00:00" is assumed. If only the seconds component is omitted, ":00" is assumed. If the[m
[56;1H           date component is omitted, the current day is assumed. Alternatively the strings "yesterday",[m
[57;1H           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
[58;1H           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
[59;1H           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
[60;1H           after the current time, respectively.[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H       [1m-F[0m, [1m--field=[0m[m
[63;1H           Print all possible data values the specified field can take in all entries of the journal.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m--system[0m, [1m--user[0m[m
[66;1H[1;1H           If the 32-character [4mID[24m is specified, it may optionally be followed by [4moffset[24m which identifies the[m
[2;1H           boot relative to the one given by boot [4mID[24m. Negative values mean earlier boots and a positive values[m
[3;1H           mean later boots. If [4moffset[24m is not specified, a value of zero is assumed, and the logs for the boot[m
[4;1H           given by [4mID[24m are shown.[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       [1m--list-boots[0m[m
[7;1H           Show a tabular list of boot numbers (relative to the current boot), their IDs, and the timestamps of[m
[8;1H           the first and last message pertaining to the boot.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       [1m-k[0m, [1m--dmesg[0m[m
[11;1H           Show only kernel messages. This implies [1m-b[0m and adds the match "_TRANSPORT=kernel".[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1m-t[0m, [1m--identifier=[0m[4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
[14;1H           Show messages for the specified syslog identifier [4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m, or for any of the messages with[m
[15;1H           a "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER" matched by [4mPATTERN[24m.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
[20;1H           Show messages for the specified systemd unit [4mUNIT[24m (such as a service unit), or for any of the units[m
[21;1H           matched by [4mPATTERN[24m. If a pattern is specified, a list of unit names found in the journal is compared[m

[23;1H           messages from the unit ("_SYSTEMD_UNIT=[4mUNIT[24m"), along with additional matches for messages from[m
[24;1H           systemd and messages about coredumps for the specified unit.[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[27;1H[m

[57;1H           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
[58;1H           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
[59;1H           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
[60;1H           after the current time, respectively.[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H       [1m-F[0m, [1m--field=[0m[m
[63;1H           Print all possible data values the specified field can take in all entries of the journal.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m--system[0m, [1m--user[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K55[K~~[K[HM[m
[HM           specified to look at logs from a different machine).[m
[HM           to specifying [1m-0[0m, except when the current boot is not the last boot (e.g. because [1m--directory[0m was[m
[HM           so on; while [1m-0[0m is the last boot, [1m-1[0m the boot before last, and so on. An empty [4moffset[24m is equivalent[m
[HM           journal. Thus, [1m1[0m means the first boot found in the journal in chronological order, [1m2[0m the second and[m
[HM           the journal, and a equal-or-less-than zero [4moffset[24m will look up boots starting from the end of the[m

[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 97/386 43% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           boot relative to the one given by boot [4mID[24m. Negative values mean earlier boots and a positive values[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 98/386 44% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           mean later boots. If [4moffset[24m is not specified, a value of zero is assumed, and the logs for the boot[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 99/386 44% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           given by [4mID[24m are shown.[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 100/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 101/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K       [1m--list-boots[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 102/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           Show a tabular list of boot numbers (relative to the current boot), their IDs, and the timestamps of[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 103/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           the first and last message pertaining to the boot.[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 104/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 105/386 45% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [1m-k[0m, [1m--dmesg[0m[m
           Show only kernel messages. This implies [1m-b[0m and adds the match "_TRANSPORT=kernel".[m
[m
       [1m-t[0m, [1m--identifier=[0m[4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified syslog identifier [4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m, or for any of the messages with[m
           a "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER" matched by [4mPATTERN[24m.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified systemd unit [4mUNIT[24m (such as a service unit), or for any of the units[m
           matched by [4mPATTERN[24m. If a pattern is specified, a list of unit names found in the journal is compared[m
           with the specified pattern and all that match are used. For each unit name, a match is added for[m
           messages from the unit ("_SYSTEMD_UNIT=[4mUNIT[24m"), along with additional matches for messages from[m
           systemd and messages about coredumps for the specified unit.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m, [1m--priority=[0m[m
           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m
           level (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log levels in the form[m
           FROM..TO. The log levels are the usual syslog log levels as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m
           "emerg" (0), "alert" (1), "crit" (2), "err" (3), "warning" (4), "notice" (5), "info" (6),[m
           "debug" (7). If a single log level is specified, all messages with this log level or a lower (hence[m
           more important) log level are shown. If a range is specified, all messages within the range are[m
           shown, including both the start and the end value of the range. This will add "PRIORITY=" matches for[m
           the specified priorities.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m, [1m--cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal specified by the passed cursor.[m
[m
       [1m--after-cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal [4mafter[24m the location specified by the this[m
           cursor. The cursor is shown when the [1m--show-cursor[0m option is used.[m
[m
       [1m--show-cursor[0m[m
           The cursor is shown after the last entry after two dashes:[m
[m
               -- cursor: s=0639...[m
[m
           The format of the cursor is private and subject to change.[m
[m
       [1m-S[0m, [1m--since=[0m, [1m-U[0m, [1m--until=[0m[m
           Start showing entries on or newer than the specified date, or on or older than the specified date,[m
           respectively. Date specifications should be of the format "2012-10-30 18:17:16". If the time part is[m
           omitted, "00:00:00" is assumed. If only the seconds component is omitted, ":00" is assumed. If the[m
           date component is omitted, the current day is assumed. Alternatively the strings "yesterday",[m
           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
           after the current time, respectively.[m
[m
       [1m-F[0m, [1m--field=[0m[m
           Print all possible data values the specified field can take in all entries of the journal.[m
[m
       [1m--system[0m, [1m--user[0m[m
           Show messages from system services and the kernel (with [1m--system[0m). Show messages from service of[m
           current user (with [1m--user[0m). If neither is specified, show all messages that the user can see.[m
[m
       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
           Show messages from a running, local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[m
       [1m-D[0m [4mDIR[24m, [1m--directory=[0m[4mDIR[24m[m
           Takes a directory path as argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           directory [4mDIR[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths.[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 170/386 65% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[m
       [1m--file=[0m[4mGLOB[24m[m
           Takes a file glob as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           files matching [4mGLOB[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths. May be specified[m
           multiple times, in which case files will be suitably interleaved.[m
[m
       [1m--root=[0m[4mROOT[24m[m
           Takes a directory path as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on catalog file[m
           hierarchy underneath the specified directory instead of the root directory (e.g.  [1m--update-catalog[0m[m
           will create [4mROOT[24m/var/lib/systemd/catalog/database).[m
[m
       [1m--new-id128[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, generate a new 128-bit ID suitable for identifying messages.[m
           This is intended for usage by developers who need a new identifier for a new message they introduce[m
           and want to make recognizable. This will print the new ID in three different formats which can be[m
           copied into source code or similar.[m
[m
       [1m--header[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, show internal header information of the journal fields accessed.[m
[m
       [1m--disk-usage[0m[m
           Shows the current disk usage of all journal files. This shows the sum of the disk usage of all[m
           archived and active journal files.[m
[m
       [1m--vacuum-size=[0m, [1m--vacuum-time=[0m[m
           Removes archived journal files until the disk space they use falls below the specified size[m
           (specified with the usual "K", "M", "G", "T" suffixes), or all journal files contain no data older[m
           than the specified timespan (specified with the usual "s", "min", "h", "days", "months", "weeks",[m
           "years" suffixes). Note that running [1m--vacuum-size=[0m has only indirect effect on the output shown by[m
           [1m--disk-usage[0m as the latter includes active journal files, while the former only operates on archived[m
           journal files.  [1m--vacuum-size=[0m and [1m--vacuum-time=[0m may be combined in a single invocation to enforce[m
           both a size and time limit on the archived journal files.[m
[m
       [1m--list-catalog[0m [1m[[0m[4m128-bit-ID...[24m][m
           List the contents of the message catalog as a table of message IDs, plus their short description[m
           strings.[m
[m
           If any [4m128-bit-ID[24ms are specified, only those entries are shown.[m
[m
       [1m--dump-catalog[0m [1m[[0m[4m128-bit-ID...[24m][m
           Show the contents of the message catalog, with entries separated by a line consisting of two dashes[m
           and the ID (the format is the same as .catalog files).[m
[m
           If any [4m128-bit-ID[24ms are specified, only those entries are shown.[m
[m
       [1m--update-catalog[0m[m
           Update the message catalog index. This command needs to be executed each time new catalog files are[m
           installed, removed, or updated to rebuild the binary catalog index.[m
[m
       [1m--setup-keys[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, generate a new key pair for Forward Secure Sealing (FSS). This[m
           will generate a sealing key and a verification key. The sealing key is stored in the journal data[m
           directory and shall remain on the host. The verification key should be stored externally. Refer to[m
           the [1mSeal=[0m option in [1mjournald.conf[0m(5) for information on Forward Secure Sealing and for a link to a[m
           refereed scholarly paper detailing the cryptographic theory it is based on.[m
[m
       [1m--force[0m[m
           When [1m--setup-keys[0m is passed and Forward Secure Sealing (FSS) has already been configured, recreate[m
           FSS keys.[m
[m
       [1m--interval=[0m[m
           Specifies the change interval for the sealing key when generating an FSS key pair with [1m--setup-keys[0m.[m
           Shorter intervals increase CPU consumption but shorten the time range of undetectable journal[m
           alterations. Defaults to 15min.[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 235/386 84% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [1m--verify[0m[m
           Check the journal file for internal consistency. If the file has been generated with FSS enabled and[m
           the FSS verification key has been specified with [1m--verify-key=[0m, authenticity of the journal file is[m
           verified.[m
[m
       [1m--verify-key=[0m[m
           Specifies the FSS verification key to use for the [1m--verify[0m operation.[m
[m
       [1m--flush[0m[m
           Asks the Journal daemon to flush any log data stored in /run/log/journal into /var/log/journal, if[m
           persistent storage is enabled. This call does not return until the operation is complete.[m
[m
       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
           Print a short help text and exit.[m
[m
       [1m--version[0m[m
           Print a short version string and exit.[m
[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m[m
           Do not pipe output into a pager.[m
[m
[1mEXIT[0m [1mSTATUS[0m[m
       On success, 0 is returned; otherwise, a non-zero failure code is returned.[m
[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_PAGER[24m[m
           Pager to use when [1m--no-pager[0m is not given; overrides [4m$PAGER[24m. Setting this to an empty string or the[m
           value "cat" is equivalent to passing [1m--no-pager[0m.[m
[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_LESS[24m[m
           Override the default options passed to [1mless[0m ("FRSXMK").[m
[m
[1mEXAMPLES[0m[m
       Without arguments, all collected logs are shown unfiltered:[m
[m
           journalctl[m
[m
       With one match specified, all entries with a field matching the expression are shown:[m
[m
           journalctl _SYSTEMD_UNIT=avahi-daemon.service[m
[m
       If two different fields are matched, only entries matching both expressions at the same time are shown:[m
[m
           journalctl _SYSTEMD_UNIT=avahi-daemon.service _PID=28097[m
[m
       If two matches refer to the same field, all entries matching either expression are shown:[m
[m
           journalctl _SYSTEMD_UNIT=avahi-daemon.service _SYSTEMD_UNIT=dbus.service[m
[m
       If the separator "+" is used, two expressions may be combined in a logical OR. The following will show[m
       all messages from the Avahi service process with the PID 28097 plus all messages from the D-Bus service[m
       (from any of its processes):[m
[m
           journalctl _SYSTEMD_UNIT=avahi-daemon.service _PID=28097 + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=dbus.service[m
[m
       Show all logs generated by the D-Bus executable:[m
[m
           journalctl /usr/bin/dbus-daemon[m
[m
       Show all kernel logs from previous boot:[m
[m
           journalctl -k -b -1[m
[m
       Show a live log display from a system service apache.service:[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 300/386 96% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K           journalctl -f -u apache[m

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:20:39]# man ^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:20:40]# journalctl -u crond[K[4Pman journalctl
[?1049h[?1h=JOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[m
       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
       entry collected.[m
[m
       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[m
       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[m
       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[m
       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[m
       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[m
       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[m
       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[m
       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[m
           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
           the journal.[m
[m
       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[m
       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[m
       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[m
           [1mshort[0m[m
               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[m
           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[m
           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mverbose[0m[m
               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[m
           [1mexport[0m[m
               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[m
           [1mjson[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
               information).[m
[m
           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
               more readable by humans.[m
[m
           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[m
           [1mcat[0m[m
               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[m
       [1m--utc[0m[m
           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 68 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [1m-x[0m, [1m--catalog[0m[m
           Augment log lines with explanation texts from the message catalog. This will add explanatory help[m
           texts to log messages in the output where this is available. These short help texts will explain the[m
           context of an error or log event, possible solutions, as well as pointers to support forums,[m
           developer documentation, and any other relevant manuals. Note that help texts are not available for[m
           all messages, but only for selected ones. For more information on the message catalog, please refer[m
           to the [1mMessage[0m [1mCatalog[0m [1mDeveloper[0m [1mDocumentation[0m[4].[m
[m
           Note: when attaching [1mjournalctl[0m output to bug reports, please do [4mnot[24m use [1m-x[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-q[0m, [1m--quiet[0m[m
           Suppresses any warning messages regarding inaccessible system journals when run as a normal user.[m
[m
       [1m-m[0m, [1m--merge[0m[m
           Show entries interleaved from all available journals, including remote ones.[m
[m
       [1m-b[0m [1m[[0m[4mID[24m][1m[[0m[4m¬±offset[24m], [1m--boot=[[0m[4mID[24m][1m[[0m[4m¬±offset[24m][m
           Show messages from a specific boot. This will add a match for "_BOOT_ID=".[m
[m
           The argument may be empty, in which case logs for the current boot will be shown.[m
[m
           If the boot ID is omitted, a positive [4moffset[24m will look up the boots starting from the beginning of[m
           the journal, and a equal-or-less-than zero [4moffset[24m will look up boots starting from the end of the[m
           journal. Thus, [1m1[0m means the first boot found in the journal in chronological order, [1m2[0m the second and[m
           so on; while [1m-0[0m is the last boot, [1m-1[0m the boot before last, and so on. An empty [4moffset[24m is equivalent[m
           to specifying [1m-0[0m, except when the current boot is not the last boot (e.g. because [1m--directory[0m was[m
           specified to look at logs from a different machine).[m
[m
           If the 32-character [4mID[24m is specified, it may optionally be followed by [4moffset[24m which identifies the[m
           boot relative to the one given by boot [4mID[24m. Negative values mean earlier boots and a positive values[m
           mean later boots. If [4moffset[24m is not specified, a value of zero is assumed, and the logs for the boot[m
           given by [4mID[24m are shown.[m
[m
       [1m--list-boots[0m[m
           Show a tabular list of boot numbers (relative to the current boot), their IDs, and the timestamps of[m
           the first and last message pertaining to the boot.[m
[m
       [1m-k[0m, [1m--dmesg[0m[m
           Show only kernel messages. This implies [1m-b[0m and adds the match "_TRANSPORT=kernel".[m
[m
       [1m-t[0m, [1m--identifier=[0m[4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified syslog identifier [4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m, or for any of the messages with[m
           a "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER" matched by [4mPATTERN[24m.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified systemd unit [4mUNIT[24m (such as a service unit), or for any of the units[m
           matched by [4mPATTERN[24m. If a pattern is specified, a list of unit names found in the journal is compared[m
           with the specified pattern and all that match are used. For each unit name, a match is added for[m
           messages from the unit ("_SYSTEMD_UNIT=[4mUNIT[24m"), along with additional matches for messages from[m
           systemd and messages about coredumps for the specified unit.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m, [1m--priority=[0m[m
           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m
           level (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log levels in the form[m
           FROM..TO. The log levels are the usual syslog log levels as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m
           "emerg" (0), "alert" (1), "crit" (2), "err" (3), "warning" (4), "notice" (5), "info" (6),[m
           "debug" (7). If a single log level is specified, all messages with this log level or a lower (hence[m
           more important) log level are shown. If a range is specified, all messages within the range are[m
           shown, including both the start and the end value of the range. This will add "PRIORITY=" matches for[m
           the specified priorities.[m
[m

[57;1H           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m
[58;1H           level (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log levels in the form[m
[59;1H           FROM..TO. The log levels are the usual syslog log levels as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m

[66;1H       [1m-c[0m, [1m--cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal specified by the passed cursor.[m
[m
       [1m--after-cursor=[0m[m
           Start showing entries from the location in the journal [4mafter[24m the location specified by the this[m
           cursor. The cursor is shown when the [1m--show-cursor[0m option is used.[m
[m
       [1m--show-cursor[0m[m
           The cursor is shown after the [7mlast[27m entry after two dashes:[m
[m
               -- cursor: s=0639...[m
[m
           The format of the cursor is private and subject to change.[m
[m
       [1m-S[0m, [1m--since=[0m, [1m-U[0m, [1m--until=[0m[m
           Start showing entries on or newer than the specified date, or on or older than the specified date,[m
           respectively. Date specifications should be of the format "2012-10-30 18:17:16". If the time part is[m
           omitted, "00:00:00" is assumed. If only the seconds component is omitted, ":00" is assumed. If the[m
           date component is omitted, the current day is assumed. Alternatively the strings "yesterday",[m
           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
           after the current time, respectively.[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 157 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM           journal. Thus, [1m1[0m means the first boot found in the journal in chronological order, [1m2[0m the second and[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 156 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM           the journal, and a equal-or-less-than zero [4moffset[24m will look up boots starting from the end of the[m

           date component is omitted, the current day is assumed. Alternatively the strings "yesterday",[m
           "today", "tomorrow" are understood, which refer to 00:00:00 of the day before the current day, the[m
           current day, or the day after the current day, respectively.  "now" refers to the current time.[m
           Finally, relative times may be specified, prefixed with "-" or "+", referring to times before or[m
           after the current time, respectively.[m

[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 157 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K       [1m-F[0m, [1m--field=[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 158 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K           Print all possible data values the specified field can take in all entries of the journal.[m
[m
       [1m--system[0m, [1m--user[0m[m
           Show messages from system services and the kernel (with [1m--system[0m). Show messages from service of[m
           current user (with [1m--user[0m). If neither is specified, show all messages that the user can see.[m
[m
       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
           Show messages from a running, local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[m
       [1m-D[0m [4mDIR[24m, [1m--directory=[0m[4mDIR[24m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 168 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K           Takes a directory path as argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           directory [4mDIR[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths.[m
[m
       [1m--file=[0m[4mGLOB[24m[m
           Takes a file glob as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on the specified journal[m
           files matching [4mGLOB[24m instead of the default runtime and system journal paths. May be specified[m
           multiple times, in which case files will be suitably interleaved.[m
[m
       [1m--root=[0m[4mROOT[24m[m
           Takes a directory path as an argument. If specified, journalctl will operate on catalog file[m
           hierarchy underneath the specified directory instead of the root directory (e.g.  [1m--update-catalog[0m[m
           will create [4mROOT[24m/var/lib/systemd/catalog/database).[m
[m
       [1m--new-id128[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, generate a new 128-bit ID suitable for identifying messages.[m
           This is intended for usage by developers who need a new identifier for a new message they introduce[m
           and want to make recognizable. This will print the new ID in three different formats which can be[m
           copied into source code or similar.[m
[m
       [1m--header[0m[m
           Instead of showing journal contents, show internal header information of the journal fields accessed.[m
[m
       [1m--disk-usage[0m[m
           Shows the current disk usage of all journal files. This shows the sum of the disk usage of all[m
           archived and active journal files.[m
[m
       [1m--vacuum-size=[0m, [1m--vacuum-time=[0m[m
           Removes archived journal files until the disk space they use falls below the specified size[m
           (specified with the usual "K", "M", "G", "T" suffixes), or all journal files contain no data older[m
           than the specified timespan (specified with the usual "s", "min", "h", "days", "months", "weeks",[m
           "years" suffixes). Note that running [1m--vacuum-size=[0m has only indirect effect on the output shown by[m
           [1m--disk-usage[0m as the latter includes active journal files, while the former only operates on archived[m
           journal files.  [1m--vacuum-size=[0m and [1m--vacuum-time=[0m may be combined in a single invocation to enforce[m
           both a size and time limit on the archived journal files.[m
[m
       [1m--list-catalog[0m [1m[[0m[4m128-bit-ID...[24m][m
           List the contents of the message catalog as a table of message IDs, plus their short description[m
           strings.[m
