[?1049h[?1h=JOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[m
       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
       entry collected.[m
[m
       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[m
       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[m
       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[m
       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[m
       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[m
       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[m
       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[m
       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[m
           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
           the journal.[m
[m
       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[m
       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[m
       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[m
           [1mshort[0m[m
               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[m
           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[m
           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mverbose[0m[m
               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[m
           [1mexport[0m[m
               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[m
           [1mjson[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
               information).[m
[m
           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
               more readable by humans.[m
[m
           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[m
           [1mcat[0m[m
               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[m
       [1m--utc[0m[m
           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 68 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:32:07]# man journalctljournalctl -f -n 10^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:32:21]# man journalctl
[?1049h[?1h=JOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[m
       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
       entry collected.[m
[m
       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
       they are automatically matched as alternatives, i.e. the resulting output will show entries matching any[m
       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m
       between other terms on the command line. This causes all matches before and after to be combined in a[m
       disjunction (i.e. logical OR).[m
[m
       As shortcuts for a few types of field/value matches, file paths may be specified. If a file path refers[m
       to an executable file, this is equivalent to an "_EXE=" match for the canonicalized binary path.[m
       Similarly, if a path refers to a device node then match is added for the kernel name of the device[m
       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m
       automatically. Device node paths are not stable across reboots, therefore match for the current boot id[m
       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m
       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[m
       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
       will be shown (logical AND).[m
[m
       Output is interleaved from all accessible journal files, whether they are rotated or currently being[m
       written, and regardless of whether they belong to the system itself or are accessible user journals.[m
[m
       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m
       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[m
       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[m
       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[m
       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[m
           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
           the journal.[m
[m
       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[m
       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[m
       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[m
           [1mshort[0m[m
               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[m
           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[m
           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mverbose[0m[m
               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[m
           [1mexport[0m[m
               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[m
           [1mjson[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
               information).[m
[m
           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
               more readable by humans.[m
[m
           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[m
           [1mcat[0m[m
               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[m
       [1m--utc[0m[m
           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 68 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K55[K~~[K[HM       [1m-a[0m, [1m--all[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM           The old options [1m-l[0m/[1m--full[0m are not useful anymore, except to undo [1m--no-full[0m.[m
[HM[m
[HM           allowing them to wrap or be truncated by the pager, if one is used.[m
[HM           Ellipsize fields when they do not fit in available columns. The default is to show full fields,[m
[HM       [1m--no-full[0m, [1m--full[0m, [1m-l[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM       The following options are understood:[m
[HM[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM       colored red; lines of level NOTICE and higher are highlighted; other lines are displayed normally.[m
[HM       When outputting to a tty, lines are colored according to priority: lines of level ERROR and higher are[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1m--no-pager[0m option and the "Environment" section below.[m
[HM       part can be viewed by using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys. Paging can be disabled; see the[m
[HM       The output is paged through [1mless[0m by default, and long lines are "truncated" to screen width. The hidden[m
[HM[m
[HM       Members of the "wheel" group can often perform administrative tasks.[m
[HM       Note that the two latter groups traditionally have additional privileges specified by the distribution.[m
[HM       other users. Members of the the "systemd-journal", "adm", and "wheel" groups can read all journal files.[m
[HM       who are members of a few special groups are granted access to the system journal and the journals of[m
[HM       All users are granted access to their private per-user journals. However, by default, only root and users[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1m--file[0m options, see below.[m
[HM       The set of journal files which will be used can be modified using the [1m--user[0m, [1m--system[0m, [1m--directory[0m, and[m

[HM[m

[HM       Additional constraints may be added using options [1m--boot[0m, [1m--unit=[0m, etc, to further limit what entries[m
[HM[m
[HM       queried by providing path to the device node.[m
[HM       ("_BOOT_ID=") is always added as well. Note that only the log entries for the existing device nodes maybe[m

[HM       ("_KERNEL_DEVICE="). Also, matches for the kernel names of all the parent devices are added[m

[HM       of the specified matches for the same field. Finally, the character "+" may appears as a separate word[m

[HM       entries matching all the specified matches of this kind. If two matches apply to the same field, then[m
[HM       matching different fields, the log entries are filtered by both, i.e. the resulting output will show only[m
[HM       entry. See [1msystemd.journal-fields[0m(7) for a list of well-known fields. If multiple matches are specified[m
[HM       "FIELD=VALUE", e.g.  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT=httpd.service", referring to the components of a structured journal[m
[HM       If one or more match arguments are passed, the output is filtered accordingly. A match is in the format[m
[HM[m
[HM       entry collected.[m
[HM       If called without parameters, it will show the full contents of the journal, starting with the oldest[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1mjournald.service[0m(8).[m
[HM       [1mjournalctl[0m may be used to query the contents of the [1msystemd[0m(1) journal as written by [1msystemd-[0m[m
[HM[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1mjournalctl[0m [OPTIONS...] [MATCHES...][m
[HM[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM       journalctl - Query the systemd journal[m
[HM[1mNAME[0m[m
[HM[m
[HMJOURNALCTL(1)                                      journalctl                                      JOURNALCTL(1)[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K           Show all fields in full, even if they include unprintable characters or are very long.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--follow[0m[m
           Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they are appended to[m
           the journal.[m
[m
       [1m-e[0m, [1m--pager-end[0m[m
           Immediately jump to the end of the journal inside the implied pager tool. This implies [1m-n1000[0m to[m
           guarantee that the pager will not buffer logs of unbounded size. This may be overridden with an[m
           explicit [1m-n[0m with some other numeric value while [1m-nall[0m will disable this cap. Note that this option is[m
           only supported for the [1mless[0m(1) pager.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m, [1m--lines=[0m[m
           Show the most recent journal events and limit the number of events shown. If [1m--follow[0m is used, this[m
           option is implied. The argument is a positive integer or "all" to disable line limiting. The default[m
           value is 10 if no argument is given.[m
[m
       [1m--no-tail[0m[m
           Show all stored output lines, even in follow mode. Undoes the effect of [1m--lines=[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reverse[0m[m
           Reverse output so that the newest entries are displayed first.[m
[m
       [1m-o[0m, [1m--output=[0m[m
           Controls the formatting of the journal entries that are shown. Takes one of the following options:[m
[m
           [1mshort[0m[m
               is the default and generates an output that is mostly identical to the formatting of classic[m
               syslog files, showing one line per journal entry.[m
[m
           [1mshort-iso[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows ISO 8601 wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mshort-precise[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows timestamps with full microsecond precision.[m
[m
           [1mshort-monotonic[0m[m
               is very similar, but shows monotonic timestamps instead of wallclock timestamps.[m
[m
           [1mverbose[0m[m
               shows the full-structured entry items with all fields.[m
[m
           [1mexport[0m[m
               serializes the journal into a binary (but mostly text-based) stream suitable for backups and[m
               network transfer (see [1mJournal[0m [1mExport[0m [1mFormat[0m[1] for more information).[m
[m
           [1mjson[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, one per line (see [1mJournal[0m [1mJSON[0m [1mFormat[0m[2] for more[m
               information).[m
[m
           [1mjson-pretty[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but formats them in multiple lines in order to make them[m
               more readable by humans.[m
[m
           [1mjson-sse[0m[m
               formats entries as JSON data structures, but wraps them in a format suitable for [1mServer-Sent[0m[m
               [1mEvents[0m[3].[m
[m
           [1mcat[0m[m
               generates a very terse output, only showing the actual message of each journal entry with no[m
               metadata, not even a timestamp.[m
[m
       [1m--utc[0m[m
           Express time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 68 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [1m-x[0m, [1m--catalog[0m[m
           Augment log lines with explanation texts from the message catalog. This will add explanatory help[m
           texts to log messages in the output where this is available. These short help texts will explain the[m
           context of an error or log event, possible solutions, as well as pointers to support forums,[m
           developer documentation, and any other relevant manuals. Note that help texts are not available for[m
           all messages, but only for selected ones. For more information on the message catalog, please refer[m
           to the [1mMessage[0m [1mCatalog[0m [1mDeveloper[0m [1mDocumentation[0m[4].[m
[m
           Note: when attaching [1mjournalctl[0m output to bug reports, please do [4mnot[24m use [1m-x[0m.[m
[m
       [1m-q[0m, [1m--quiet[0m[m
           Suppresses any warning messages regarding inaccessible system journals when run as a normal user.[m
[m
       [1m-m[0m, [1m--merge[0m[m
           Show entries interleaved from all available journals, including remote ones.[m
[m
       [1m-b[0m [1m[[0m[4mID[24m][1m[[0m[4m¬±offset[24m], [1m--boot=[[0m[4mID[24m][1m[[0m[4m¬±offset[24m][m
           Show messages from a specific boot. This will add a match for "_BOOT_ID=".[m
[m
           The argument may be empty, in which case logs for the current boot will be shown.[m
[m
           If the boot ID is omitted, a positive [4moffset[24m will look up the boots starting from the beginning of[m
           the journal, and a equal-or-less-than zero [4moffset[24m will look up boots starting from the end of the[m
           journal. Thus, [1m1[0m means the first boot found in the journal in chronological order, [1m2[0m the second and[m
           so on; while [1m-0[0m is the last boot, [1m-1[0m the boot before last, and so on. An empty [4moffset[24m is equivalent[m
           to specifying [1m-0[0m, except when the current boot is not the last boot (e.g. because [1m--directory[0m was[m
           specified to look at logs from a different machine).[m
[m
           If the 32-character [4mID[24m is specified, it may optionally be followed by [4moffset[24m which identifies the[m
           boot relative to the one given by boot [4mID[24m. Negative values mean earlier boots and a positive values[m
           mean later boots. If [4moffset[24m is not specified, a value of zero is assumed, and the logs for the boot[m
           given by [4mID[24m are shown.[m
[m
       [1m--list-boots[0m[m
           Show a tabular list of boot numbers (relative to the current boot), their IDs, and the timestamps of[m
           the first and last message pertaining to the boot.[m
[m
       [1m-k[0m, [1m--dmesg[0m[m
           Show only kernel messages. This implies [1m-b[0m and adds the match "_TRANSPORT=kernel".[m
[m
       [1m-t[0m, [1m--identifier=[0m[4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified syslog identifier [4mSYSLOG_IDENTIFIER[24m, or for any of the messages with[m
           a "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER" matched by [4mPATTERN[24m.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--unit=[0m[4mUNIT[24m[1m|[0m[4mPATTERN[24m[m
           Show messages for the specified systemd unit [4mUNIT[24m (such as a service unit), or for any of the units[m
           matched by [4mPATTERN[24m. If a pattern is specified, a list of unit names found in the journal is compared[m
           with the specified pattern and all that match are used. For each unit name, a match is added for[m
           messages from the unit ("_SYSTEMD_UNIT=[4mUNIT[24m"), along with additional matches for messages from[m
           systemd and messages about coredumps for the specified unit.[m
[m
           This parameter can be specified multiple times.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m, [1m--priority=[0m[m
           Filter output by message priorities or priority ranges. Takes either a single numeric or textual log[m
           level (i.e. between 0/"emerg" and 7/"debug"), or a range of numeric/text log levels in the form[m
           FROM..TO. The log levels are the usual syslog log levels as documented in [1msyslog[0m(3), i.e.[m
           "emerg" (0), "alert" (1), "crit" (2), "err" (3), "warning" (4), "notice" (5), "info" (6),[m
           "debug" (7). If a single log level is specified, all messages with this log level or a lower (hence[m
           more important) log level are shown. If a range is specified, all messages within the range are[m
           shown, including both the start and the end value of the range. This will add "PRIORITY=" matches for[m
           the specified priorities.[m
[m
[7m Manual page journalctl(1) line 133 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:32:46]# man journalctljournalctl -f -n 10[K[K[K[K[K[K[Kt msg
[?1h=-- Logs begin at ven. 2019-02-15 11:05:33 CET, end at ven. 2019-02-15 11:21:23 CET. --[m
f√©vr. 15 11:10:34 vm0.pcocc msg[1593]: [1;39mWhere this msg will be sent?[0m[m
[K[?1l>]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:32:49]# journalctl -t msg[K[K[Kfoo
[?1h=-- Logs begin at ven. 2019-02-15 11:05:33 CET, end at ven. 2019-02-15 11:21:23 CET. --[m
f√©vr. 15 11:09:34 vm0.pcocc foo[1575]: [1;31mUnable to write to file /tmp/foo[0m[m
[K[?1l>]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:32:57]# man rsyslog
Aucune entr√©e de manuel pour rsyslog
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:33:43]# man rsyslog[C[C[C[C[C[C[C^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:33:51]# man rsyslogd
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOGD(8)                                Linux System Administration                               RSYSLOGD(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslogd - reliable and extended syslogd[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mrsyslogd[0m [ [1m-d[0m ] [ [1m-D[0m ] [ [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-n[0m ] [ [1m-N[0m [4mlevel[24m ] [ [1m-C[0m ] [ [1m-v[0m ][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m  is  a  system utility providing support for message logging.  Support of both internet and unix[m
       domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages  only  covers  basic  aspects  of operation.  [1mFor[0m [1mdetails[0m [1mand[0m [1mconfiguration[0m [1mexamples,[0m [1msee[0m [1mthe[0m [1mrsys‚Äê[0m[m
       [1mlog.conf[0m [1m(5)[0m [1mman[0m [1mpage[0m [1mand[0m [1mthe[0m [1monline[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1mat[0m [1mhttp://www.rsyslog.com/doc[0m[m
[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m(8) is derived from the sysklogd package which in turn is derived from the stock BSD sources.[m
[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m provides a kind of logging that many modern programs use.   Every  logged  message  contains  at[m
       least a time and a hostname field, normally a program name field, too, but that depends on how trusty the[m
       logging program is. The rsyslog package supports free definition of output formats via templates. It also[m
       supports precise timestamps and writing directly to databases. If the database option is used, tools like[m
       phpLogCon can be used to view the log data.[m
[m
       While the [1mrsyslogd[0m sources have been heavily modified a couple of notes are in order.  First of all there[m
       has  been  a  systematic  attempt  to ensure that rsyslogd follows its default, standard BSD behavior. Of[m
       course, some configuration file changes are necessary in order to support the template  system.  However,[m
       rsyslogd  should  be  able  to  use a standard syslog.conf and act like the original syslogd. However, an[m
       original syslogd will not work correctly with a rsyslog-enhanced configuration file.  At  best,  it  will[m
       generate funny looking file names.  The second important concept to note is that this version of rsyslogd[m
       interacts transparently with the version of syslog found in the standard libraries.  If a  binary  linked[m
       to  the  standard  shared libraries fails to function correctly we would like an example of the anomalous[m
       behavior.[m
[m
       The main configuration file [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m or an alternative file, given with the [1m-f[0m option,  is  read[m
       at  startup.   Any  lines that begin with the hash mark (``#'') and empty lines are ignored.  If an error[m
       occurs during parsing the error element is ignored. It is tried to parse the rest of the line.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       [1m-D[0m     Runs the Bison config parser in debug mode. This may help when hard  to  find  syntax  errors  are[m
              reported. Please note that the output generated is deeply technical and orignally targeted towards[m
              developers.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m     Turns on debug mode. See the DEBUGGING section for more information.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m[m
              Specify an alternative configuration file instead of [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m, which is the default.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m[m
              Specify an alternative pid file instead of the default one.  This option must be used if  multiple[m
              instances of rsyslogd should run on a single machine.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m     Avoid  auto-backgrounding.  This is needed especially if the [1mrsyslogd[0m is started and controlled by[m
              [1minit[0m(8).[m
[m
       [1m-N[0m  [1mlevel[0m[m
              Do a coNfig check. Do NOT run in regular mode, just check configuration  file  correctness.   This[m
              option is meant to verify a config file. To do so, run rsyslogd interactively in foreground, spec‚Äê[m
              ifying -f <config-file> and -N level.  The level argument modifies behaviour. Currently, 0 is  the[m
              same as not specifying the -N option at all (so this makes limited sense) and 1 actually activates[m
              the code. Later, higher levels will mean more verbosity (this is a forward-compatibility option).[m
[m
       [1m-C[0m     This prevents rsyslogd from changing to the root directory. This is almost never a  good  idea  in[m
[7m Manual page rsyslogd(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kcc[Koo[Knn[Kff[K[1;1HRSYSLOGD(8)                                Linux System Administration                               RSYSLOGD(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslogd - reliable and extended syslogd[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mrsyslogd[0m [ [1m-d[0m ] [ [1m-D[0m ] [ [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-n[0m ] [ [1m-N[0m [4mlevel[24m ] [ [1m-C[0m ] [ [1m-v[0m ][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m  is  a  system utility providing support for message logging.  Support of both internet and unix[m
[11;1H       domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[14;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[15;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[16;1H       pages  only  covers  basic  aspects  of operation.  [1mFor[0m [1mdetails[0m [1mand[0m [1mconfiguration[0m [1mexamples,[0m [1msee[0m [1mthe[0m [1mrsys‚Äê[0m[m
[17;1H       [1mlog.conf[0m [1m(5)[0m [1mman[0m [1mpage[0m [1mand[0m [1mthe[0m [1monline[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1mat[0m [1mhttp://www.rsyslog.com/doc[0m[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m(8) is derived from the sysklogd package which in turn is derived from the stock BSD sources.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m provides a kind of logging that many modern programs use.   Every  logged  message  contains  at[m
[22;1H       least a time and a hostname field, normally a program name field, too, but that depends on how trusty the[m
[23;1H       logging program is. The rsyslog package supports free definition of output formats via templates. It also[m
[24;1H       supports precise timestamps and writing directly to databases. If the database option is used, tools like[m
[25;1H       phpLogCon can be used to view the log data.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       While the [1mrsyslogd[0m sources have been heavily modified a couple of notes are in order.  First of all there[m
[28;1H       has  been  a  systematic  attempt  to ensure that rsyslogd follows its default, standard BSD behavior. Of[m
[29;1H       course, some configuration file changes are necessary in order to support the template  system.  However,[m
[30;1H       rsyslogd  should  be  able  to  use a standard syslog.conf and act like the original syslogd. However, an[m
[31;1H       original syslogd will not work correctly with a rsyslog-enhanced configuration file.  At  best,  it  will[m
[32;1H       generate funny looking file names.  The second important concept to note is that this version of rsyslogd[m
[33;1H       interacts transparently with the version of syslog found in the standard libraries.  If a  binary  linked[m
[34;1H       to  the  standard  shared libraries fails to function correctly we would like an example of the anomalous[m
[35;1H       behavior.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       The main configuration file [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m or an alternative file, given with the [1m-f[0m option,  is  read[m
[38;1H       at  startup.   Any  lines that begin with the hash mark (``#'') and empty lines are ignored.  If an error[m
[39;1H       occurs during parsing the error element is ignored. It is tried to parse the rest of the line.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[42;1H       [1m-D[0m     Runs the Bison config parser in debug mode. This may help when hard  to  find  syntax  errors  are[m
[43;1H              reported. Please note that the output generated is deeply technical and orignally targeted towards[m
[44;1H              developers.[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       [1m-d[0m     Turns on debug mode. See the DEBUGGING section for more information.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m[m
[49;1H              Specify an alternative configuration file instead of [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m, which is the default.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m[m
[52;1H              Specify an alternative pid file instead of the default one.  This option must be used if  multiple[m
[53;1H              instances of rsyslogd should run on a single machine.[m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       [1m-n[0m     Avoid  auto-backgrounding.  This is needed especially if the [1mrsyslogd[0m is started and controlled by[m
[56;1H              [1minit[0m(8).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1m-N[0m  [1mlevel[0m[m
[59;1H              Do a coNfig check. Do NOT run in regular mode, just check configuration  file  correctness.   This[m
[60;1H              option is meant to verify a config file. To do so, run rsyslogd interactively in foreground, spec‚Äê[m
[61;1H              ifying -f <config-file> and -N level.  The level argument modifies behaviour. Currently, 0 is  the[m
[62;1H              same as not specifying the -N option at all (so this makes limited sense) and 1 actually activates[m
[63;1H              the code. Later, higher levels will mean more verbosity (this is a forward-compatibility option).[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m-C[0m     This prevents rsyslogd from changing to the root directory. This is almost never a  good  idea  in[m
[66;1H[1;1HRSYSLOGD(8)                                Linux System Administration                               RSYSLOGD(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslogd - reliable and extended syslogd[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mrsyslogd[0m [ [1m-d[0m ] [ [1m-D[0m ] [ [1m-f[0m [4m[7mconf[27m[24m[4mig[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-n[0m ] [ [1m-N[0m [4mlevel[24m ] [ [1m-C[0m ] [ [1m-v[0m ][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m  is  a  system utility providing support for message logging.  Support of both internet and unix[m
[11;1H       domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[14;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[15;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[16;1H       pages  only  covers  basic  aspects  of operation.  [1mFor[0m [1mdetails[0m [1mand[0m [1m[7mconf[27m[0m[1miguration[0m [1mexamples,[0m [1msee[0m [1mthe[0m [1mrsys‚Äê[0m[m
[17;1H       [1mlog.[0m[1m[7mconf[27m[0m [1m(5)[0m [1mman[0m [1mpage[0m [1mand[0m [1mthe[0m [1monline[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1mat[0m [1mhttp://www.rsyslog.com/doc[0m[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m(8) is derived from the sysklogd package which in turn is derived from the stock BSD sources.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1mRsyslogd[0m provides a kind of logging that many modern programs use.   Every  logged  message  contains  at[m
[22;1H       least a time and a hostname field, normally a program name field, too, but that depends on how trusty the[m
[23;1H       logging program is. The rsyslog package supports free definition of output formats via templates. It also[m
[24;1H       supports precise timestamps and writing directly to databases. If the database option is used, tools like[m
[25;1H       phpLogCon can be used to view the log data.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       While the [1mrsyslogd[0m sources have been heavily modified a couple of notes are in order.  First of all there[m
[28;1H       has  been  a  systematic  attempt  to ensure that rsyslogd follows its default, standard BSD behavior. Of[m
[29;1H       course, some [7mconf[27miguration file changes are necessary in order to support the template  system.  However,[m
[30;1H       rsyslogd  should  be  able  to  use a standard syslog.[7mconf[27m and act like the original syslogd. However, an[m
[31;1H       original syslogd will not work correctly with a rsyslog-enhanced [7mconf[27miguration file.  At  best,  it  will[m
[32;1H       generate funny looking file names.  The second important concept to note is that this version of rsyslogd[m
[33;1H       interacts transparently with the version of syslog found in the standard libraries.  If a  binary  linked[m
[34;1H       to  the  standard  shared libraries fails to function correctly we would like an example of the anomalous[m
[35;1H       behavior.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       The main [7mconf[27miguration file [4m/etc/rsyslog.[24m[4m[7mconf[27m[24m or an alternative file, given with the [1m-f[0m option,  is  read[m
[38;1H       at  startup.   Any  lines that begin with the hash mark (``#'') and empty lines are ignored.  If an error[m
[39;1H       occurs during parsing the error element is ignored. It is tried to parse the rest of the line.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[42;1H       [1m-D[0m     Runs the Bison [7mconf[27mig parser in debug mode. This may help when hard  to  find  syntax  errors  are[m
[43;1H              reported. Please note that the output generated is deeply technical and orignally targeted towards[m
[44;1H              developers.[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       [1m-d[0m     Turns on debug mode. See the DEBUGGING section for more information.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       [1m-f[0m [4m[7mconf[27m[24m[4mig[24m [4mfile[24m[m
[49;1H              Specify an alternative [7mconf[27miguration file instead of [4m/etc/rsyslog.[24m[4m[7mconf[27m[24m, which is the default.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m[m
[52;1H              Specify an alternative pid file instead of the default one.  This option must be used if  multiple[m
[53;1H              instances of rsyslogd should run on a single machine.[m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       [1m-n[0m     Avoid  auto-backgrounding.  This is needed especially if the [1mrsyslogd[0m is started and controlled by[m
[56;1H              [1minit[0m(8).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1m-N[0m  [1mlevel[0m[m
[59;1H              Do a [7mcoNf[27mig check. Do NOT run in regular mode, just check [7mconf[27miguration  file  correctness.   This[m
[60;1H              option is meant to verify a [7mconf[27mig file. To do so, run rsyslogd interactively in foreground, spec‚Äê[m
[61;1H              ifying -f <[7mconf[27mig-file> and -N level.  The level argument modifies behaviour. Currently, 0 is  the[m
[62;1H              same as not specifying the -N option at all (so this makes limited sense) and 1 actually activates[m
[63;1H              the code. Later, higher levels will mean more verbosity (this is a forward-compatibility option).[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m-C[0m     This prevents rsyslogd from changing to the root directory. This is almost never a  good  idea  in[m
[66;1H              production use. This option was introduced in support of the internal testbed.[m
[m
       [1m-v[0m     Print version and exit.[m
[m
[1mSIGNALS[0m[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m reacts to a set of signals.  You may easily send a signal to [1mrsyslogd[0m using the following:[m
[7m Manual page rsyslogd(8) line 9 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[m
              kill -SIGNAL $(cat /var/run/rsyslogd.pid)[m
[m
       Note  that  -SIGNAL  must be replaced with the actual signal you are trying to send, e.g. with HUP. So it[m
       then becomes:[m
[m
              kill -HUP $(cat /var/run/rsyslogd.pid)[m
[m
       [1mHUP[0m    This lets [1mrsyslogd[0m perform close all open files.[m
[m
       [1mTERM[0m [1m,[0m  [1mINT[0m [1m,[0m  [1mQUIT[0m[m
              [1mRsyslogd[0m will die.[m
[m
       [1mUSR1[0m   Switch debugging on/off.  This option can only be used if [1mrsyslogd[0m is started with  the  [1m-d[0m  debug[m
              option.[m
[m
       [1mCHLD[0m   Wait for childs if some were born, because of wall'ing messages.[m
[m
[1mSECURITY[0m [1mTHREATS[0m[m
       There is the potential for the rsyslogd daemon to be used as a conduit for a denial of service attack.  A[m
       rogue program(mer) could very easily flood the rsyslogd daemon with syslog messages resulting in the  log[m
       files consuming all the remaining space on the filesystem.  Activating logging over the inet domain sock‚Äê[m
       ets will of course expose a system to risks outside of programs or individuals on the local machine.[m
[m
       There are a number of methods of protecting a machine:[m
[m
       1.     Implement kernel firewalling to limit which hosts or networks have access to the 514/UDP socket.[m
[m
       2.     Logging can be directed to an isolated or non-root filesystem which, if filled,  will  not  impair[m
              the machine.[m
[m
       3.     The  ext2  filesystem  can  be  used  which  can  be [7mconf[27migured to limit a certain percentage of a[m
              filesystem to usage by root only.  [1mNOTE[0m that this will require rsyslogd to be run  as  a  non-root[m
              process.  [1mALSO[0m [1mNOTE[0m that this will prevent usage of remote logging on the default port since rsys‚Äê[m
              logd will be unable to bind to the 514/UDP socket.[m
[m
       4.     Disabling inet domain sockets will limit risk to the local machine.[m
[m
   [1mMessage[0m [1mreplay[0m [1mand[0m [1mspoofing[0m[m
       If remote logging is enabled, messages can easily be spoofed and replayed.  As the messages are transmit‚Äê[m
       ted  in clear-text, an attacker might use the information obtained from the packets for malicious things.[m
       Also, an attacker might replay recorded messages or spoof a sender's IP address, which could  lead  to  a[m
       wrong  perception  of system activity. These can be prevented by using GSS-API authentication and encryp‚Äê[m
       tion. Be sure to think about syslog network security before enabling it.[m
[m
[1mDEBUGGING[0m[m
       When debugging is turned on using the [1m-d[0m option, [1mrsyslogd[0m produces debugging information according to the[m
       [1mRSYSLOG_DEBUG[0m  environment  variable and the signals received. When run in foreground, the information is[m
       written to stdout. An additional output file can be  specified  using  the  [1mRSYSLOG_DEBUGLOG[0m  environment[m
       variable.[m
[m
[1mFILES[0m[m
       [4m/etc/rsyslog.[24m[4m[7mconf[27m[24m[m
              [7mConf[27miguration file for [1mrsyslogd[0m.  See [1mrsyslog.[0m[1m[7mconf[27m[0m(5) for exact information.[m
       [4m/dev/log[24m[m
              The Unix domain socket to from where local syslog messages are read.[m
       [4m/var/run/rsyslogd.pid[24m[m
              The file containing the process id of [1mrsyslogd[0m.[m
       [4mprefix/lib/rsyslog[24m[m
              Default  directory  for  [1mrsyslogd[0m  modules.  The  [4mprefix[24m  is  specified  during  compilation (e.g.[m
              /usr/local).[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       [1mRSYSLOG_DEBUG[0m[m
              Controls runtime debug support. It contains an option string with the following  options  possible[m
              (all are case insensitive):[m
[7m Manual page rsyslogd(8) line 75/195 75% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K55[K~~[K[HM       [1mRsyslogd[0m reacts to a set of signals.  You may easily send a signal to [1mrsyslogd[0m using the following:[m
[HM[1mSIGNALS[0m[m

[HM       to  the  standard  shared libraries fails to function correctly we would like an example of the anomalous[m
[HM       interacts transparently with the version of syslog found in the standard libraries.  If a  binary  linked[m
[HM       generate funny looking file names.  The second important concept to note is that this version of rsyslogd[m
[HM       original syslogd will not work correctly with a rsyslog-enhanced [7mconf[27miguration file.  At  best,  it  will[m
[HM       rsyslogd  should  be  able  to  use a standard syslog.[7mconf[27m and act like the original syslogd. However, an[m
[HM       course, some [7mconf[27miguration file changes are necessary in order to support the template  system.  However,[m
[HM       has  been  a  systematic  attempt  to ensure that rsyslogd follows its default, standard BSD behavior. Of[m
[HM       While the [1mrsyslogd[0m sources have been heavily modified a couple of notes are in order.  First of all there[m
[HM[m
[HM       phpLogCon can be used to view the log data.[m
[HM       supports precise timestamps and writing directly to databases. If the database option is used, tools like[m
[HM       logging program is. The rsyslog package supports free definition of output formats via templates. It also[m
[HM       least a time and a hostname field, normally a program name field, too, but that depends on how trusty the[m
[HM       [1mRsyslogd[0m provides a kind of logging that many modern programs use.   Every  logged  message  contains  at[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1mRsyslogd[0m(8) is derived from the sysklogd package which in turn is derived from the stock BSD sources.[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1mlog.[0m[1m[7mconf[27m[0m [1m(5)[0m [1mman[0m [1mpage[0m [1mand[0m [1mthe[0m [1monline[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1mat[0m [1mhttp://www.rsyslog.com/doc[0m[m
[HM       pages  only  covers  basic  aspects  of operation.  [1mFor[0m [1mdetails[0m [1mand[0m [1m[7mconf[27m[0m[1miguration[0m [1mexamples,[0m [1msee[0m [1mthe[0m [1mrsys‚Äê[0m[m
[HM       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[HM       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[HM       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[HM[m
[HM       domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.[m
[HM       [1mRsyslogd[0m  is  a  system utility providing support for message logging.  Support of both internet and unix[m
[HM[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[HM[m
[HM       [1mrsyslogd[0m [ [1m-d[0m ] [ [1m-D[0m ] [ [1m-f[0m [4m[7mconf[27m[24m[4mig[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-n[0m ] [ [1m-N[0m [4mlevel[24m ] [ [1m-C[0m ] [ [1m-v[0m ][m

[HM       rsyslogd - reliable and extended syslogd[m

[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslogd(8) line 1/195 41% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:34:17]# less /etc/rsyy[Kslog.l[K
rsyslog.conf  rsyslog.d/    
[root@vm0 11:34:17]# less /etc/rsyslog.conf .
[?1049h[?1h=# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

[7m/etc/rsyslog.conf (file 1 of 2)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K# Everybody gets emergency messages
*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*

# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
uucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler

# Save boot messages also to boot.log
local7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log


# ### begin forwarding rule ###
# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###
[7m(END) - Next: .[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7m(END) - Next: .[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:34:56]# less /etc/rsyslog.conf .

[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# Provides UDP syslog reception
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM#### MODULES ####
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# rsyslog configuration file

Aucune entr√©e de manuel pour rsyslogd.conf
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:38:03]# man rsyslogd.conf[1P.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [4mimgssapi[24m[m
              Input plugin for plain TCP and GSS-enable syslog[m
[m
       [4mimmark[24m Support for mark messages[m
[m
       [4mimklog[24m Kernel logging. To include kernel log messages, you need to do[m
[m
              $ModLoad imklog[m
[m
              Please  note  that  the klogd daemon is no longer necessary and consequently no longer pro‚Äê[m
              vided by the rsyslog package.[m
[m
       [4mimuxsock[24m[m
              Unix sockets, including the system log socket. You need to specify[m
[m
              $ModLoad imuxsock[m
[m
              in order to receive log messages from local system processes. This config directive  should[m
              only left out if you know exactly what you are doing.[m
[m
[1mBASIC[0m [1mSTRUCTURE[0m[m
       Lines  starting  with  a hash mark ('#') and empty lines are ignored.  Rsyslog.conf should contain[m
       following sections (sorted by recommended order in file):[m
[m
       Global directives[m
              Global directives set some global properties of whole rsyslog daemon, for example  size  of[m
              main  message queue ($MainMessageQueueSize), loading external modules ($ModLoad) and so on.[m
              All global directives need to be specified on a line by their own and  must  start  with  a[m
              dollar-sign.  The  complete list of global directives can be found in html documentation in[m
              doc directory or online on web pages.[m
[m
       Templates[m
              Templates allow you to specify format of the logged message. They are also used for dynamic[m
              file  name generation. They have to be defined before they are used in rules. For more info[m
              about templates see TEMPLATES section of this manpage.[m
[m
       Output channels[m
              Output channels provide an umbrella for any type of output that the user might want.   They[m
              have  to  be defined before they are used in rules. For more info about output channels see[m
              OUTPUT CHANNELS section of this manpage.[m
[m
       Rules (selector + action)[m
              Every rule line consists of two fields, a selector field and an  action  field.  These  two[m
              fields  are separated by one or more spaces or tabs. The selector field specifies a pattern[m
              of facilities and priorities belonging to the specified action.[m
[m
[1mSELECTORS[0m[m
       The selector field itself again consists of two parts, a facility and a priority, separated  by  a[m
       period  ('.').  Both  parts are case insensitive and can also be specified as decimal numbers, but[m
       don't do that, you have been warned.  Both facilities and priorities are described  in  syslog(3).[m
       The names mentioned below correspond to the similar LOG_-values in /usr/include/syslog.h.[m
[m
       The  facility  is  one  of  the following keywords: auth, authpriv, cron, daemon, kern, lpr, mail,[m
       mark, news, security (same as auth), syslog, user, uucp and local0  through  local7.  The  keyword[m
       security  should not be used anymore and mark is only for internal use and therefore should not be[m
       used in applications.  Anyway, you may want to specify  and  redirect  these  messages  here.  The[m
       facility  specifies  the  subsystem that produced the message, i.e. all mail programs log with the[m
       mail facility (LOG_MAIL) if they log using syslog.[m
[m
       The priority is one of the following keywords, in ascending order: debug, info,  notice,  warning,[m
       warn  (same  as warning), err, error (same as err), crit, alert, emerg, panic (same as emerg). The[m
       keywords error, warn and panic are deprecated and should not be used anymore. The priority defines[m
       the severity of the message.[m
[m
       The behavior of the original BSD syslogd is that all messages of the specified priority and higher[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 72 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:38:17]# man rsyslog.confd.confls /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-8.24.0/rsyslog_conf.html[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[28Pess /etc/rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

[7m/etc/rsyslog.conf[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:38:22]# less /etc/rsyslog.conf[6Pman rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m

[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Krr[Kuu[Kll[Kee[Kss[K[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
