# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# ### begin forwarding rule ###
:[K[K/[Kjj[Koo[Kuu[Krr[Knn[Kaa[Kll[Kss[Ktt[Kaa[Ktt[Kee[K[1;1H#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

[4;1H#$ModLoad imudp
[5;1H#$UDPServerRun 514
[6;1H
[7;1H# Provides TCP syslog reception
[8;1H#$ModLoad imtcp
[9;1H#$InputTCPServerRun 514
[10;1H
[11;1H
[12;1H#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####
[13;1H
[14;1H# Where to place auxiliary files
[15;1H$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog
[16;1H
[17;1H# Use default timestamp format
[18;1H$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat
[19;1H
[20;1H# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
[21;1H# not useful and an extreme performance hit
[22;1H#$ActionFileEnableSync on
[23;1H
[24;1H# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
[25;1H$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
[26;1H
[27;1H# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
[28;1H# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
[29;1H$OmitLocalLogging on
[30;1H
[31;1H# File to store the position in the journal
[32;1H$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state
[33;1H
[34;1H
[35;1H#### RULES ####
[36;1H
[37;1H# Log all kernel messages to the console.
[38;1H# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
[39;1H#kern.*                                                 /dev/console
[40;1H
[41;1H# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
[42;1H# Don't log private authentication messages!
[43;1H*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages
[44;1H
[45;1H# The authpriv file has restricted access.
[46;1Hauthpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure
[47;1H
[48;1H# Log all the mail messages in one place.
[49;1Hmail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog
[50;1H
[51;1H
[52;1H# Log cron stuff
[53;1Hcron.*                                                  /var/log/cron
[54;1H
[55;1H# Everybody gets emergency messages
[56;1H*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*
[57;1H
[58;1H# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
[59;1Huucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler
[60;1H
[61;1H# Save boot messages also to boot.log
[62;1Hlocal7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log
[63;1H

[66;1H# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###

[HM# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
[HM
[HM#$ActionFileEnableSync on
[HM# not useful and an extreme performance hit
[HM# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
[HM
[HM$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat
[HM# Use default timestamp format
[HM

[HM# Where to place auxiliary files

[HM

[HM#$InputTCPServerRun 514
[HM#$ModLoad imtcp

[HM# Provides UDP syslog reception
[HM
[HM#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability
[HM#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
[HM$ModLoad [7mimjournal[27m # provides access to the systemd journal
[HM$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
[HM# The [7mimjournal[27m module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
[HM
[HM#### MODULES ####
[HM
[HM# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html
[HM# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html

[9;1H$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
[10;1H$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
[11;1H#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
[12;1H#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

[35;1H# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
[36;1H$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
[37;1H
[38;1H# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
[39;1H# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
[40;1H$OmitLocalLogging on
[41;1H
[42;1H# File to store the position in the journal
[43;1H$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state
[44;1H
[45;1H
[46;1H#### RULES ####
[47;1H
[48;1H# Log all kernel messages to the console.
[49;1H# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
[50;1H#kern.*                                                 /dev/console
[51;1H
[52;1H# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
[53;1H# Don't log private authentication messages!
[54;1H*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages
[55;1H
[56;1H# The authpriv file has restricted access.
[57;1Hauthpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure
[58;1H
[59;1H# Log all the mail messages in one place.
[60;1Hmail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog
[61;1H
[62;1H
[63;1H# Log cron stuff
[64;1Hcron.*                                                  /var/log/cron
[65;1H
[66;1H# Everybody gets emergency messages
*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*

# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
uucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler

# Save boot messages also to boot.log
local7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log


# ### begin forwarding rule ###
# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# Provides TCP syslog reception
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM#$UDPServerRun 514
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM#$ModLoad imudp
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# Provides UDP syslog reception
[66;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[66;1H[K:[K[K/[Kii[Kmm[Kjj[Koo[Kuu[Krr[Knn[Kaa[Kll[K[1;1H
[2;1H# Provides UDP syslog reception
[3;1H#$ModLoad imudp
[4;1H#$UDPServerRun 514
[5;1H
[6;1H# Provides TCP syslog reception
[7;1H#$ModLoad imtcp
[8;1H#$InputTCPServerRun 514
[9;1H
[10;1H
[11;1H#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####
[12;1H
[13;1H# Where to place auxiliary files
[14;1H$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog
[15;1H
[16;1H# Use default timestamp format
[17;1H$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat
[18;1H
[19;1H# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
[20;1H# not useful and an extreme performance hit
[21;1H#$ActionFileEnableSync on
[22;1H
[23;1H# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
[24;1H$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
[25;1H
[26;1H# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
[27;1H# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
[28;1H$OmitLocalLogging on
[29;1H
[30;1H# File to store the position in the journal
[31;1H$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state
[32;1H

# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###

[HM# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
[HM
[HM#$ActionFileEnableSync on
[HM# not useful and an extreme performance hit
[HM# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
[HM
[HM$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat
[HM# Use default timestamp format
[HM

[HM# Where to place auxiliary files
[HM
[HM#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

[HM
[HM#$InputTCPServerRun 514
[HM#$ModLoad imtcp
[HM# Provides TCP syslog reception
[HM
[HM#$UDPServerRun 514
[HM#$ModLoad imudp
[HM# Provides UDP syslog reception
[HM
[HM#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability
[HM#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
[HM$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
[HM$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
[HM# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
[HM
[HM#### MODULES ####
[HM
[HM# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html
[HM# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html

[10;1H$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal

[42;1H# File to store the position in the journal
[43;1H$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state
[44;1H
[45;1H
[46;1H#### RULES ####
[47;1H
[48;1H# Log all kernel messages to the console.
[49;1H# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
[50;1H#kern.*                                                 /dev/console
[51;1H
[52;1H# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
[53;1H# Don't log private authentication messages!
[54;1H*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages
[55;1H
[56;1H# The authpriv file has restricted access.
[57;1Hauthpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure
[58;1H
[59;1H# Log all the mail messages in one place.
[60;1Hmail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog
[61;1H
[62;1H
[63;1H# Log cron stuff
[64;1Hcron.*                                                  /var/log/cron
[65;1H
[66;1H[1;1H# rsyslog configuration file
[2;1H
[3;1H# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
[4;1H# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html
[5;1H
[6;1H#### MODULES ####
[7;1H
[8;1H# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
[9;1H$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
[10;1H$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
[11;1H#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
[12;1H#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability
[13;1H
[14;1H# Provides UDP syslog reception
[15;1H#$ModLoad imudp
[16;1H#$UDPServerRun 514
[17;1H
[18;1H# Provides TCP syslog reception
[19;1H#$ModLoad imtcp
[20;1H#$InputTCPServerRun 514
[21;1H
[22;1H
[23;1H#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####
[24;1H
[25;1H# Where to place auxiliary files
[26;1H$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog
[27;1H
[28;1H# Use default timestamp format
[29;1H$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat
[30;1H
[31;1H# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
[32;1H# not useful and an extreme performance hit
[33;1H#$ActionFileEnableSync on
[34;1H
[35;1H# Include all config files in /etc/[7mrsyslog.d[27m/
[36;1H$IncludeConfig /etc/[7mrsyslog.d[27m/*.conf
[37;1H
[38;1H# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
[39;1H# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
[40;1H$OmitLocalLogging on
[41;1H
[42;1H# File to store the position in the journal
[43;1H$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state
[44;1H
[45;1H
[46;1H#### RULES ####
[47;1H
[48;1H# Log all kernel messages to the console.
[49;1H# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
[50;1H#kern.*                                                 /dev/console
[51;1H
[52;1H# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
[53;1H# Don't log private authentication messages!
[54;1H*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages
[55;1H
[56;1H# The authpriv file has restricted access.
[57;1Hauthpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure
[58;1H
[59;1H# Log all the mail messages in one place.
[60;1Hmail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog
[61;1H
[62;1H
[63;1H# Log cron stuff
[64;1Hcron.*                                                  /var/log/cron
[65;1H
[66;1H# Everybody gets emergency messages
*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*

# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
uucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler

# Save boot messages also to boot.log
local7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log


# ### begin forwarding rule ###
# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###
[1m~[0m

[1m~[0m
[1m~[0m
[1m~[0m
[1m~[0m

# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
uucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler

# Save boot messages also to boot.log
local7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log


# ### begin forwarding rule ###
# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###

[?1049h[?1h=# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:51:25]# vim /etc/rsyslog.d/local2.conf[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[8Pless /etc/rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

[7m/etc/rsyslog.conf[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:51:32]# fg

# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

$OmitLocalLogging on

$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

[7m/etc/rsyslog.conf[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K# Everybody gets emergency messages
*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*

# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
uucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler

# Save boot messages also to boot.log
local7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log


# ### begin forwarding rule ###
# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
#
# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
# remote host is: name/ip:port, e.g. 192.168.0.1:514, port optional
#*.* @@remote-host:514
# ### end of the forwarding rule ###
[7m(END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:51:41]# fg

[?1l>[?12l[?25h[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:51:55]# service restart rsyslog
The service command supports only basic LSB actions (start, stop, restart, try-restart, reload, force-reload, status). For other actions, please try to use systemctl.
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:52:17]# service restart rsyslog[1P[1P[1P[1P[1P[1P[1P rsyslog[1Prsyslog[C[C[C[C[C[C[C restart
Redirecting to /bin/systemctl restart rsyslog.service
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:52:25]# man service
[?1049h[?1h=service(8)                                   System Manager's Manual                                  service(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       service - run a System V init script[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mservice[0m [4mSCRIPT[24m [4mCOMMAND[24m [[4mOPTIONS[24m][m
[m
       [1mservice[0m [1m--status-all[0m[m
[m
       [1mservice[0m [1m--help[0m | [1m-h[0m | [1m--version[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mservice[0m  runs a System V init script in as predictable environment as possible, removing most environment[m
       variables and with current working directory set to [1m/[0m.[m
[m
       The [4mSCRIPT[24m parameter specifies a System V init script, located in [1m/etc/init.d/[0m[4mSCRIPT[24m.  The supported val‚Äê[m
       ues  of  [4mCOMMAND[24m  depend  on the invoked script, [1mservice[0m passes [4mCOMMAND[24m and [4mOPTIONS[24m it to the init script[m
       unmodified.  All scripts should support at least the [1mstart[0m and [1mstop[0m commands.  As a special case, if [4mCOM‚Äê[24m[m
       [4mMAND[24m  is  [1m--full-restart[0m,  the script is run twice, first with the [1mstop[0m command, then with the [1mstart[0m com‚Äê[m
       mand.[m
[m
       [1mservice[0m [1m--status-all[0m runs all init scripts, in alphabetical order, with the [1mstatus[0m command.[m
[m
       If the init script file does not exist, the script tries to use [1mlegacy[0m [1mactions.[0m  If there is no  suitable[m
       legacy  action  found  and  [4mCOMMAND[24m is one of actions specified in LSB Core Specification, input is redi‚Äê[m
       rected to the [1msystemctl.[0m  Otherwise the command fails with return code 2.[m
[m
[1mFILES[0m[m
       [1m/etc/init.d[0m[m
              The directory containing System V init scripts.[m
[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       [1mLANG[0m, [1mTERM[0m[m
              The only environment variables passed to the init scripts.[m
[m
[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
       [1mchkconfig[0m(8), [1mntsysv(8),[0m [1msystemd[0m(1), [1msystemctl[0m(8), [1msystemd.service[0m(5)[m
[m
                                                    Jan 2006                                          service(8)[m
[7m Manual page service(8) line 1/49 (END) (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:52:43]# man service --status-al

       [1mservice[0m  runs a System V init script in as predictable environment as possible, removing most environment[m

       mand.[m

       [1mservice[0m [1m--status-all[0m runs all init scripts, in alphabetical order, with the [1mstatus[0m command.[m
[m
       If the init script file does not exist, the script tries to use [1mlegacy[0m [1mactions.[0m  If there is no  suitable[m
       legacy  action  found  and  [4mCOMMAND[24m is one of actions specified in LSB Core Specification, input is redi‚Äê[m
       rected to the [1msystemctl.[0m  Otherwise the command fails with return code 2.[m

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:53:45]# [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[Cl': pgrep -l rsysloge': less /etc/rsyslog.conf[1@s[C[C[C[1@s[C[C[C[5P[root@vm0 11:53:45]#[C
[?1049h[?1h=# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*                                                 /dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none                /var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*                                              /var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  -/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*                                                  /var/log/cron

21-cloudinit.conf  listen.conf  local2.conf

[7m/etc/rsyslog.conf[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Everybody gets emergency messages
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K*.emerg                                                 :omusrmsg:*
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Save news errors of level crit and higher in a special file.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kuucp,news.crit                                          /var/log/spooler
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Save boot messages also to boot.log
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Klocal7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# ### begin forwarding rule ###
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Remote Logging (we use TCP for reliable delivery)
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# An on-disk queue is created for this action. If the remote host is
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# down, messages are spooled to disk and sent when it is up again.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#$ActionQueueFileName fwdRule1 # unique name prefix for spool files
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#$ActionQueueMaxDiskSpace 1g   # 1gb space limit (use as much as possible)
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#$ActionQueueSaveOnShutdown on # save messages to disk on shutdown
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#$ActionQueueType LinkedList   # run asynchronously
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K#$ActionResumeRetryCount -1    # infinite retries if host is down
:[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 11:55:30]# less /etc/rsyslog.conf[4Ps /etc/rsyslog.d/

# comment out the following line to allow CLOUDINIT messages through.

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Save boot messages also to boot.log
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Klocal7.*                                                /var/log/boot.log
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# ### begin forwarding rule ###
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The statement between the begin ... end define a SINGLE forwarding
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# rule. They belong together, do NOT split them. If you create multiple
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# forwarding rules, duplicate the whole block!

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:01:58]# man rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kjj[Koo[Kuu[Krr[Knn[Kaa[Kll[Kcc[Ktt[Kll[K  [K--[Kuu[K  [Kcc[Krr[Koo[Knn[Kdd[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[KPP[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K--[KBB[Kaa[Kss[Kee[Kdd[K[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[2;1H[m

[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m

[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m

[66;1H[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m

[8;1H       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
[9;1H       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
[10;1H       can rename it and it should work.[m

[13;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[14;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m

   [1m[7mProperty-Based[27m[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       Property-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[m
       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. Property names and compare operations[m
       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
       is as follows:[m
[m
              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[m
       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[m
              [1mcontains[0m[m
                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[m
              [1misequal[0m[m
                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[m
              [1mstartswith[0m[m
                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[m
              [1mregex[0m[m
                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[m
   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[m
[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[m
       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
       options. A sample is:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[m
       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[m
       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[m
       To escape:[m
          % = \%[m
          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[m
       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[m
       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[m
       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:02:52]# grep /var/log/ toto

[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [4mimgssapi[24m[m
              Input plugin for plain TCP and GSS-enable syslog[m
[m
       [4mimmark[24m Support for mark messages[m
[m
       [4mimklog[24m Kernel logging. To include kernel log messages, you need to do[m
[m
              $ModLoad imklog[m
[m
              Please  note  that  the klogd daemon is no longer necessary and consequently no longer pro‚Äê[m
              vided by the rsyslog package.[m
[m
       [4mimuxsock[24m[m
              Unix sockets, including the system log socket. You need to specify[m
[m
              $ModLoad imuxsock[m
[m
              in order to receive log messages from local system processes. This config directive  should[m
              only left out if you know exactly what you are doing.[m
[m
[1mBASIC[0m [1mSTRUCTURE[0m[m
       Lines  starting  with  a hash mark ('#') and empty lines are ignored.  Rsyslog.conf should contain[m
       following sections (sorted by recommended order in file):[m
[m
       Global directives[m
              Global directives set some global properties of whole rsyslog daemon, for example  size  of[m
              main  message queue ($MainMessageQueueSize), loading external modules ($ModLoad) and so on.[m
              All global directives need to be specified on a line by their own and  must  start  with  a[m
              dollar-sign.  The  complete list of global directives can be found in html documentation in[m
              doc directory or online on web pages.[m
[m
       Templates[m
              Templates allow you to specify format of the logged message. They are also used for dynamic[m
              file  name generation. They have to be defined before they are used in rules. For more info[m
              about templates see TEMPLATES section of this manpage.[m
[m
       Output channels[m
              Output channels provide an umbrella for any type of output that the user might want.   They[m
              have  to  be defined before they are used in rules. For more info about output channels see[m
              OUTPUT CHANNELS section of this manpage.[m
[m
       Rules (selector + action)[m
              Every rule line consists of two fields, a selector field and an  action  field.  These  two[m
              fields  are separated by one or more spaces or tabs. The selector field specifies a pattern[m
              of facilities and priorities belonging to the specified action.[m
[m
[1mSELECTORS[0m[m
       The selector field itself again consists of two parts, a facility and a priority, separated  by  a[m
       period  ('.').  Both  parts are case insensitive and can also be specified as decimal numbers, but[m
       don't do that, you have been warned.  Both facilities and priorities are described  in  syslog(3).[m
       The names mentioned below correspond to the similar LOG_-values in /usr/include/syslog.h.[m
[m
       The  facility  is  one  of  the following keywords: auth, authpriv, cron, daemon, kern, lpr, mail,[m
       mark, news, security (same as auth), syslog, user, uucp and local0  through  local7.  The  keyword[m
       security  should not be used anymore and mark is only for internal use and therefore should not be[m
       used in applications.  Anyway, you may want to specify  and  redirect  these  messages  here.  The[m
       facility  specifies  the  subsystem that produced the message, i.e. all mail programs log with the[m
       mail facility (LOG_MAIL) if they log using syslog.[m
[m
       The priority is one of the following keywords, in ascending order: debug, info,  notice,  warning,[m
       warn  (same  as warning), err, error (same as err), crit, alert, emerg, panic (same as emerg). The[m
       keywords error, warn and panic are deprecated and should not be used anymore. The priority defines[m
       the severity of the message.[m
[m
       The behavior of the original BSD syslogd is that all messages of the specified priority and higher[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 72 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[KPP[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K--[KBB[Kaa[Kss[Kee[Kdd[K[1;1H       [4mimgssapi[24m[m
[2;1H              Input plugin for plain TCP and GSS-enable syslog[m
[3;1H[m
[4;1H       [4mimmark[24m Support for mark messages[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       [4mimklog[24m Kernel logging. To include kernel log messages, you need to do[m
[7;1H[m
[8;1H              $ModLoad imklog[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H              Please  note  that  the klogd daemon is no longer necessary and consequently no longer pro‚Äê[m
[11;1H              vided by the rsyslog package.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       [4mimuxsock[24m[m
[14;1H              Unix sockets, including the system log socket. You need to specify[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H              $ModLoad imuxsock[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H              in order to receive log messages from local system processes. This config directive  should[m
[19;1H              only left out if you know exactly what you are doing.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H[1mBASIC[0m [1mSTRUCTURE[0m[m
[22;1H       Lines  starting  with  a hash mark ('#') and empty lines are ignored.  Rsyslog.conf should contain[m
[23;1H       following sections (sorted by recommended order in file):[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H       Global directives[m
[26;1H              Global directives set some global properties of whole rsyslog daemon, for example  size  of[m
[27;1H              main  message queue ($MainMessageQueueSize), loading external modules ($ModLoad) and so on.[m
[28;1H              All global directives need to be specified on a line by their own and  must  start  with  a[m
[29;1H              dollar-sign.  The  complete list of global directives can be found in html documentation in[m
[30;1H              doc directory or online on web pages.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       Templates[m
[33;1H              Templates allow you to specify format of the logged message. They are also used for dynamic[m
[34;1H              file  name generation. They have to be defined before they are used in rules. For more info[m
[35;1H              about templates see TEMPLATES section of this manpage.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       Output channels[m
[38;1H              Output channels provide an umbrella for any type of output that the user might want.   They[m
[39;1H              have  to  be defined before they are used in rules. For more info about output channels see[m
[40;1H              OUTPUT CHANNELS section of this manpage.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       Rules (selector + action)[m
[43;1H              Every rule line consists of two fields, a selector field and an  action  field.  These  two[m
[44;1H              fields  are separated by one or more spaces or tabs. The selector field specifies a pattern[m
[45;1H              of facilities and priorities belonging to the specified action.[m
[46;1H[m
[47;1H[1mSELECTORS[0m[m
[48;1H       The selector field itself again consists of two parts, a facility and a priority, separated  by  a[m
[49;1H       period  ('.').  Both  parts are case insensitive and can also be specified as decimal numbers, but[m
[50;1H       don't do that, you have been warned.  Both facilities and priorities are described  in  syslog(3).[m
[51;1H       The names mentioned below correspond to the similar LOG_-values in /usr/include/syslog.h.[m
[52;1H[m

[54;1H       mark, news, security (same as auth), syslog, user, uucp and local0  through  local7.  The  keyword[m

[56;1H       used in applications.  Anyway, you may want to specify  and  redirect  these  messages  here.  The[m
[57;1H       facility  specifies  the  subsystem that produced the message, i.e. all mail programs log with the[m

[59;1H[m
[60;1H       The priority is one of the following keywords, in ascending order: debug, info,  notice,  warning,[m
[61;1H       warn  (same  as warning), err, error (same as err), crit, alert, emerg, panic (same as emerg). The[m
[62;1H       keywords error, warn and panic are deprecated and should not be used anymore. The priority defines[m
[63;1H       the severity of the message.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       The behavior of the original BSD syslogd is that all messages of the specified priority and higher[m

[27;1H              main  message queue ($MainMessageQueueSize), loading external modules ($ModLoad) and so on.[m

[66;1H...skipping...
   [1m[7mProperty-Based[27m[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       Property-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[m
       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. Property names and compare operations[m
       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
       is as follows:[m
[m
              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[m
       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[m
              [1mcontains[0m[m
                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[m
              [1misequal[0m[m
                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[m
              [1mstartswith[0m[m
                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[m
              [1mregex[0m[m
                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[m
   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[m
[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[m
       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
       options. A sample is:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[m
       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[m
       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[m
       To escape:[m
          % = \%[m
          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[m
       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[m
       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[m
       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K       like "/var/log/system-localhost.log"[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 303 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM   [1m[7mProperty-Based[27m[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:04:51]# vi /etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf

[?1l>[?1049l
[1]+  Stopp√©                 vi /etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:05:28]# vi /etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[13Pman rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[KPP[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
[8;1H       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
[9;1H       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
[10;1H       can rename it and it should work.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[13;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[14;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[15;1H       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mMODULES[0m[m
[18;1H       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
[19;1H       tion for their full description.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [4momgssapi[24m[m
[24;1H              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [4mommysql[24m[m
[27;1H              Output module for MySQL[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
[30;1H              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [4mompgsql[24m[m
[37;1H              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
[40;1H              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H              $ModLoad imudp[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
[57;1H              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
[60;1H              used like this:[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
[8;1H       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
[9;1H       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
[10;1H       can rename it and it should work.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[13;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[14;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[15;1H       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mMODULES[0m[m
[18;1H       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
[19;1H       tion for their full description.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [4momgssapi[24m[m
[24;1H              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [4mommysql[24m[m
[27;1H              Output module for MySQL[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
[30;1H              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [4mompgsql[24m[m
[37;1H              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
[40;1H              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H              $ModLoad imudp[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
[57;1H              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
[60;1H              used like this:[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H...skipping...
   [1m[7mProperty[27m[0m[1m-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       [7mProperty[27m-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[m
       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. [7mProperty[27m names and compare operations[m
       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
       is as follows:[m
[m
              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[m
       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[m
              [1mcontains[0m[m
                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[m
              [1misequal[0m[m
                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[m
              [1mstartswith[0m[m
                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[m
              [1mregex[0m[m
                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[m
   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[m
[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[m
       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
       options. A sample is:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[m
       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[m
       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[m
       To escape:[m
          % = \%[m
          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[m
       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[m
       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[m
       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kss[Ktt[Koo[Kpp[K[1;1H   [1mProperty-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[2;1H       Property-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
[3;1H       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[4;1H[m
[5;1H       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
[6;1H       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
[7;1H       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
[8;1H       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. Property names and compare operations[m
[9;1H       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
[10;1H       is as follows:[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H              [1mcontains[0m[m
[17;1H                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H              [1misequal[0m[m
[20;1H                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
[21;1H                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H              [1mstartswith[0m[m
[24;1H                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H              [1mregex[0m[m
[27;1H                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[30;1H       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
[33;1H       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
[34;1H       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
[35;1H       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
[36;1H       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
[39;1H       options. A sample is:[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
[44;1H       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
[45;1H       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[46;1H[m
[47;1H       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
[48;1H       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
[49;1H       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
[50;1H       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H       To escape:[m
[53;1H          % = \%[m
[54;1H          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
[55;1H       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
[60;1H       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
[61;1H       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[66;1H[1;1H   [1mProperty-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[2;1H       Property-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
[3;1H       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[4;1H[m
[5;1H       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
[6;1H       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
[7;1H       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
[8;1H       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. Property names and compare operations[m
[9;1H       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
[10;1H       is as follows:[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H              [1mcontains[0m[m
[17;1H                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H              [1misequal[0m[m
[20;1H                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
[21;1H                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H              [1mstartswith[0m[m
[24;1H                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H              [1mregex[0m[m
[27;1H                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[30;1H       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m

[36;1H       will find the hardcoded ones.[m

[39;1H       options. A sample is:[m

[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K/[Kpp[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Ktt[Ktt[Kyy[K[K[K[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K[1;1H   [1mProperty-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
[2;1H       Property-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
[3;1H       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[4;1H[m
[5;1H       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
[6;1H       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
[7;1H       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
[8;1H       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. Property names and compare operations[m
[9;1H       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
[10;1H       is as follows:[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H              [1mcontains[0m[m
[17;1H                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H              [1misequal[0m[m
[20;1H                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
[21;1H                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H              [1mstartswith[0m[m
[24;1H                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[25;1H[m

[27;1H                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
