[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 501 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM              the "static" part of the tag,  as  defined  by  BSD  syslogd.  For  example,  when  TAG  is[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 500 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       [1mprogramname[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 499 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 498 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM              TAG from the message[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 497 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       [1msyslogtag[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 496 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 495 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM              immediately in front of us and not necessarily the original sender)[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 494 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM              hostname  of the system the message was received from (in a relay chain, this is the system[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 493 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:09:29]# fg

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:10:27]# fgman rsyslog.conffg[Kman rsyslog.conffg[Kman rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[KPP[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m

[57;1H              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
[60;1H              used like this:[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H...skipping...
   [1m[7mProperty[27m[0m[1m-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       [7mProperty[27m-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[m
       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. [7mProperty[27m names and compare operations[m
       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
       is as follows:[m
[m
              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[m
       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[m
              [1mcontains[0m[m
                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[m
              [1misequal[0m[m
                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[m
              [1mstartswith[0m[m
                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[m
              [1mregex[0m[m
                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[m
   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[m
[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[m
       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
       options. A sample is:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[m
       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[m
       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[m
       To escape:[m
          % = \%[m
          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[m
       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[m
       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[m
       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:10:33]# vi /etc/rsyslog.lo[K[Kconf 
[?1049h[?1h=[1;66r[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[66;1H"/etc/rsyslog.conf" 91L, 3232C[1;1H# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*[49C/dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none[16C/var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*[46C/var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*[50C-/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*[50C/var/log/cron[1;1H[?12l[?25h












[?25l[66;1H[K[66;1H/[?12l[?25h/[?25l[66;2H[K[66;2H[?12l[?25h [14;1H[13;1H[?25l[66;1H:[?12l[?25hq[?25l[66;1H[K[66;1H[?1l>[?12l[?25h[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:11:02]# vi /etc/rsyslog.conf [5Pman rsyslog.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:11:04]# fg
vi /etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf
[?1049h[?1h=[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[1;1H# :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"
:syslogfacility-text, isequal, "local2"
:syslogtag, isequal, "appli1"

              [65;1H~                                                                                                                  [3;28H[?12l[?25h[66;1H
[m[?1l>[?1049l
[1]+  Stopp√©                 vi /etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf

[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOGD(8)                                Linux System Administration                               RSYSLOGD(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslogd - reliable and extended syslogd[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mrsyslogd[0m [ [1m-d[0m ] [ [1m-D[0m ] [ [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m ] [ [1m-n[0m ] [ [1m-N[0m [4mlevel[24m ] [ [1m-C[0m ] [ [1m-v[0m ][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m  is  a  system utility providing support for message logging.  Support of both internet and unix[m
       domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages  only  covers  basic  aspects  of operation.  [1mFor[0m [1mdetails[0m [1mand[0m [1mconfiguration[0m [1mexamples,[0m [1msee[0m [1mthe[0m [1mrsys‚Äê[0m[m
       [1mlog.conf[0m [1m(5)[0m [1mman[0m [1mpage[0m [1mand[0m [1mthe[0m [1monline[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1mat[0m [1mhttp://www.rsyslog.com/doc[0m[m
[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m(8) is derived from the sysklogd package which in turn is derived from the stock BSD sources.[m
[m
       [1mRsyslogd[0m provides a kind of logging that many modern programs use.   Every  logged  message  contains  at[m
       least a time and a hostname field, normally a program name field, too, but that depends on how trusty the[m
       logging program is. The rsyslog package supports free definition of output formats via templates. It also[m
       supports precise timestamps and writing directly to databases. If the database option is used, tools like[m
       phpLogCon can be used to view the log data.[m
[m
       While the [1mrsyslogd[0m sources have been heavily modified a couple of notes are in order.  First of all there[m
       has  been  a  systematic  attempt  to ensure that rsyslogd follows its default, standard BSD behavior. Of[m
       course, some configuration file changes are necessary in order to support the template  system.  However,[m
       rsyslogd  should  be  able  to  use a standard syslog.conf and act like the original syslogd. However, an[m
       original syslogd will not work correctly with a rsyslog-enhanced configuration file.  At  best,  it  will[m
       generate funny looking file names.  The second important concept to note is that this version of rsyslogd[m
       interacts transparently with the version of syslog found in the standard libraries.  If a  binary  linked[m
       to  the  standard  shared libraries fails to function correctly we would like an example of the anomalous[m
       behavior.[m
[m
       The main configuration file [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m or an alternative file, given with the [1m-f[0m option,  is  read[m
       at  startup.   Any  lines that begin with the hash mark (``#'') and empty lines are ignored.  If an error[m
       occurs during parsing the error element is ignored. It is tried to parse the rest of the line.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       [1m-D[0m     Runs the Bison config parser in debug mode. This may help when hard  to  find  syntax  errors  are[m
              reported. Please note that the output generated is deeply technical and orignally targeted towards[m
              developers.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m     Turns on debug mode. See the DEBUGGING section for more information.[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m [4mconfig[24m [4mfile[24m[m
              Specify an alternative configuration file instead of [4m/etc/rsyslog.conf[24m, which is the default.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m [4mpid[24m [4mfile[24m[m
              Specify an alternative pid file instead of the default one.  This option must be used if  multiple[m
              instances of rsyslogd should run on a single machine.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m     Avoid  auto-backgrounding.  This is needed especially if the [1mrsyslogd[0m is started and controlled by[m
              [1minit[0m(8).[m
[m
       [1m-N[0m  [1mlevel[0m[m
              Do a coNfig check. Do NOT run in regular mode, just check configuration  file  correctness.   This[m
              option is meant to verify a config file. To do so, run rsyslogd interactively in foreground, spec‚Äê[m
              ifying -f <config-file> and -N level.  The level argument modifies behaviour. Currently, 0 is  the[m
              same as not specifying the -N option at all (so this makes limited sense) and 1 actually activates[m
              the code. Later, higher levels will mean more verbosity (this is a forward-compatibility option).[m
[m
       [1m-C[0m     This prevents rsyslogd from changing to the root directory. This is almost never a  good  idea  in[m
[7m Manual page rsyslogd(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:11:39]# man rsyslogd[K.conf
[?1049h[?1h=RSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
       can rename it and it should work.[m
[m
       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[m
[1mMODULES[0m[m
       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
       tion for their full description.[m
[m
       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[m
       [4momgssapi[24m[m
              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[m
       [4mommysql[24m[m
              Output module for MySQL[m
[m
       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[m
              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[m
       [4mompgsql[24m[m
              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[m
       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[m
       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[m
       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imudp[m
[m
              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[m
              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[m
       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
              used like this:[m
[m
              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[m
              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[KPP[Krr[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Ktt[K[Krr[Ktt[Kyy[K[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
[8;1H       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
[9;1H       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
[10;1H       can rename it and it should work.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[13;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[14;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[15;1H       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mMODULES[0m[m
[18;1H       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
[19;1H       tion for their full description.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [4momgssapi[24m[m
[24;1H              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [4mommysql[24m[m
[27;1H              Output module for MySQL[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
[30;1H              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [4mompgsql[24m[m
[37;1H              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
[40;1H              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H              $ModLoad imudp[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
[57;1H              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
[60;1H              used like this:[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1HRSYSLOG.CONF(5)                            Linux System Administration                           RSYSLOG.CONF(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       rsyslog.conf - rsyslogd(8) configuration file[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [4mrsyslog.conf[24m  file  is the main configuration file for the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8) which logs system messages on[m
[8;1H       *nix systems.  This file specifies rules for logging.  For special features see the [1mrsyslogd[0m(8)  manpage.[m
[9;1H       Rsyslog.conf is backward-compatible with sysklogd's syslog.conf file. So if you migrate from sysklogd you[m
[10;1H       can rename it and it should work.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       [1mNote[0m [1mthat[0m [1mthis[0m [1mversion[0m [1mof[0m [1mrsyslog[0m [1mships[0m [1mwith[0m [1mextensive[0m [1mdocumentation[0m [1min[0m [1mhtml[0m [1mformat.[0m  This is provided in[m
[13;1H       the  ./doc  subdirectory and probably in a separate package if you installed rsyslog via a packaging sys‚Äê[m
[14;1H       tem.  To use rsyslog's advanced features, you [1mneed[0m to look at the html  documentation,  because  the  man[m
[15;1H       pages only cover basic aspects of operation.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mMODULES[0m[m
[18;1H       Rsyslog has a modular design. Consequently, there is a growing number of modules. See the html documenta‚Äê[m
[19;1H       tion for their full description.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [4momsnmp[24m SNMP trap output module[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [4momgssapi[24m[m
[24;1H              Output module for GSS-enabled syslog[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [4mommysql[24m[m
[27;1H              Output module for MySQL[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H       [4momrelp[24m Output module for the reliable RELP protocol (prevents message loss).  For details, see  below  at[m
[30;1H              imrelp and the html documentation.  It can be used like this:[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H              *.*  :omrelp:server:port[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H              *.*  :omrelp:192.168.0.1:2514 # actual sample[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [4mompgsql[24m[m
[37;1H              Output module for PostgreSQL[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [4momlibdbi[24m[m
[40;1H              Generic database output module (Firebird/Interbase, MS SQL, Sybase, SQLite, Ingres, Oracle, mSQL)[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [4mimfile[24m Input module for text files[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       [4mimudp[24m  Input plugin for UDP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -r option. Can be used like this:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H              $ModLoad imudp[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H              $UDPServerRun 514[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       [4mimtcp[24m  Input plugin for plain TCP syslog. Replaces the deprecated -t option. Can be used like this:[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H              $ModLoad imtcp[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H              $InputTCPServerRun 514[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [4mimrelp[24m Input  plugin for the RELP protocol. RELP can be used instead of UDP or plain TCP syslog to[m
[57;1H              provide reliable delivery of syslog messages. Please note that plain TCP  syslog  does  NOT[m
[58;1H              provide  truly  reliable  delivery, with it messages may be lost when there is a connection[m
[59;1H              problem or the server shuts down.  RELP prevents message loss in those cases.   It  can  be[m
[60;1H              used like this:[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H              $ModLoad imrelp[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              $InputRELPServerRun 2514[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H...skipping...
   [1m[7mProperty[27m[0m[1m-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       [7mProperty[27m-based  filters  are  unique to rsyslogd. They allow to filter on any property, like HOST‚Äê[m
       NAME, syslogtag and msg.[m
[m
       A property-based filter must start with a colon in column 0. This tells rsyslogd that  it  is  the[m
       new filter type. The colon must be followed by the property name, a comma, the name of the compare[m
       operation to carry out, another comma and then the value to compare against. This  value  must  be[m
       quoted.   There  can  be spaces and tabs between the commas. [7mProperty[27m names and compare operations[m
       are case-sensitive, so "msg" works, while "MSG" is an invalid property name. In brief, the  syntax[m
       is as follows:[m
[m
              :property, [!]compare-operation, "value"[m
[m
       The following compare-operations are currently supported:[m
[m
              [1mcontains[0m[m
                     Checks if the string provided in value is contained in the property[m
[m
              [1misequal[0m[m
                     Compares  the  "value"  string  provided and the property contents. These two values[m
                     must be exactly equal to match.[m
[m
              [1mstartswith[0m[m
                     Checks if the value is found exactly at the beginning of the property value[m
[m
              [1mregex[0m[m
                     Compares the property against the provided regular expression.[m
[m
   [1mExpression-Based[0m [1mFilters[0m[m
       See the html documentation for this feature.[m
[m
[1mTEMPLATES[0m[m
       Every output in rsyslog uses templates - this holds true for files, user messages and so on.  Tem‚Äê[m
       plates  compatible  with  the stock syslogd formats are hardcoded into rsyslogd. If no template is[m
       specified, we use one of these hardcoded templates. Search for "template_" in  syslogd.c  and  you[m
       will find the hardcoded ones.[m
[m
       A  template  consists  of  a  template  directive,  a  name, the actual template text and optional[m
       options. A sample is:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mMyTemplateName,"\7Text[0m [1m%property%[0m [1msome[0m [1mmore[0m [1mtext\n",<options>[0m[m
[m
       The "$template" is the template directive. It tells rsyslog that this line  contains  a  template.[m
       The  backslash is an escape character. For example, \7 rings the bell (this is an ASCII value), \n[m
       is a new line. The set in rsyslog is a bit restricted currently.[m
[m
       All text in the template is used literally, except for things  within  percent  signs.  These  are[m
       properties and allow you access to the contents of the syslog message. Properties are accessed via[m
       the property replacer and it can for example pick a substring or do date-specific formatting. More[m
       on this is the PROPERTY REPLACER section of this manpage.[m
[m
       To escape:[m
          % = \%[m
          \ = \\ --> '\' is used to escape (as in C)[m
       $template TraditionalFormat,"%timegenerated% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag%%msg%\n"[m
[m
       Properties can be accessed by the property replacer (see there for details).[m
[m
       [1mPlease[0m  [1mnote[0m  [1mthat[0m  [1mtemplates[0m [1mcan[0m [1malso[0m [1mby[0m [1mused[0m [1mto[0m [1mgenerate[0m [1mselector[0m [1mlines[0m [1mwith[0m [1mdynamic[0m [1mfile[0m [1mnames.[0m[m
       For example, if you would like to split syslog messages from different hosts  to  different  files[m
       (one per host), you can define the following template:[m
[m
              [1m$template[0m [1mDynFile,"/var/log/system-%HOSTNAME%.log"[0m[m
[m
       This  template can then be used when defining an output selector line. It will result in something[m
[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 302 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 301 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       and offer the best performance for this job.[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 299 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       facility, you should do this with selector lines. They are not second-class  citizens  in  rsyslog[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 298 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       ibility  with  stock syslogd configuration files. If you just need to filter based on priority and[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 297 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       with their original syntax, because it is well-known, highly effective and also needed for compat‚Äê[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 296 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       [1mSelectors[0m  [1mare[0m  [1mthe[0m  [1mtraditional[0m [1mway[0m [1mof[0m [1mfiltering[0m [1msyslog[0m [1mmessages.[0m  They have been kept in rsyslog[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 295 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM   [1mSelectors[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 294 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 293 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM          * expression-based filters[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 291 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM          * property-based filters[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 290 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM          * "traditional" severity and facility based selectors[m

[66;1H[K[7m Manual page rsyslog.conf(5) line 283 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m

[?1049h[?1h=[1;66r[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[66;1H"/etc/rsyslog.conf" 91L, 3232C[1;1H# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514


#### GLOBAL DIRECTIVES ####

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state


#### RULES ####

# Log all kernel messages to the console.
# Logging much else clutters up the screen.
#kern.*[49C/dev/console

# Log anything (except mail) of level info or higher.
# Don't log private authentication messages!
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none[16C/var/log/messages

# The authpriv file has restricted access.
authpriv.*[46C/var/log/secure

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*[50C-/var/log/maillog


# Log cron stuff
cron.*[50C/var/log/cron[1;1H[?12l[?25h[?25l[66;1H[K[66;1H:[?12l[?25hq![?25l[66;1H[K[66;1H[?1l>[?12l[?25h[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 12:12:56]# [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[C[22@v': vi /etc/rsyslog.conf[1@i[C[C[C[C[Cm /etc/rsyslog.d/local2.conf[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[9P /etc/rsyslog.conf [C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[Cd/appli1.conf[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[3P[root@vm0 12:12:56]#[C

[?1049h[?1h=[1;66r[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[66;1H"/etc/rsyslog.conf" 91L, 3232C[1;1H# rsyslog configuration file

# For more information see /usr/share/doc/rsyslog-*/rsyslog_conf.html
# If you experience problems, see http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/troubleshoot.html

#### MODULES ####

# The imjournal module bellow is now used as a message source instead of imuxsock.
$ModLoad imuxsock # provides support for local system logging (e.g. via logger command)
$ModLoad imjournal # provides access to the systemd journal
#$ModLoad imklog # reads kernel messages (the same are read from journald)
#$ModLoad immark  # provides --MARK-- message capability

# Provides UDP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imudp
#$UDPServerRun 514

# Provides TCP syslog reception
#$ModLoad imtcp
#$InputTCPServerRun 514

# Where to place auxiliary files
$WorkDirectory /var/lib/rsyslog

# Use default timestamp format
$ActionFileDefaultTemplate RSYSLOG_TraditionalFileFormat

# File syncing capability is disabled by default. This feature is usually not required,
# not useful and an extreme performance hit
#$ActionFileEnableSync on

# Include all config files in /etc/rsyslog.d/
$IncludeConfig /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf

# Turn off message reception via local log socket;
# local messages are retrieved through imjournal now.
$OmitLocalLogging on

# File to store the position in the journal
$IMJournalStateFile imjournal.state

                                                                       [54;1H~        [60;1H~                                                                                                                  [61;1H~                                                                                                                  [62;1H~                                                                                                                  [63;1H~               [65;1H~                                                                                                                  [1;1H[?12l[?25h

[?25l[m[66;1H[1m-- INSERT --[m[66;13H[K[3;1H[?12l[?25h[29C[?25l*[?12l[?25h[?25l[3;30H[K[3;30H[?12l[?25h[?25l[4;1H[K[4;1H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;1H[K[5;1H[?12l[?25h[?25lauthpriv.*[46C/var/log/secure[6;1H[K[6;1H[?12l[?25h[?25l[1m[34m~                                                                                                                  [5;72H[?12l[?25h[38C[?25l[m[5;71H[K[5;71H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;70H[K[5;70H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;69H[K[5;69H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;68H[K[5;68H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;67H[K[5;67H[?12l[?25h[?25l[5;66H[K[5;66H[?12l[?25h[?25ll[?12l[?25h[?25lo[?12l[?25h[?25lc[?12l[?25h[?25la[?12l[?25h[?25ll[?12l[?25h[?25l2[?12l[?25h[?25l-[?12l[?25h[?25la[?12l[?25h[?25ll[?12l[?25h[?25ll[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;75H[K[5;56H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;74H[K[5;55H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;73H[K[5;54H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;72H[K[5;53H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;71H[K[5;52H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;70H[K[5;51H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;69H[K[5;50H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;68H[K[5;49H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;67H[K[5;48H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;66H[K[5;47H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;65H[K[5;46H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;64H[K[5;45H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;63H[K[5;44H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;62H[K[5;43H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;61H[K[5;42H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;60H[K[5;41H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;59H[K[5;40H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;58H[K[5;39H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;57H[K[5;38H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;56H[K[5;37H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;55H[K[5;36H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;54H[K[5;35H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;53H[K[5;34H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;52H[K[5;33H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;51H[K[5;32H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;50H[K[5;31H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;49H[K[5;30H[?12l[?25h[?25l/var/log/local2-al[5;48H[K[5;29H[?12l[?25h[?2 /var/log/local2-al[5;35H[K[5;8H[?12l[?25h[?25l.*      /var/log/local2-al[5;34H[K[5;7H[?12l[?25h[?25l.*      /var/log/local2-al[5;33H[K[5;6H[?12l[?25h[?25l.* /var/log/local2-alllo[?12l[?25h[?25lc.*      /var/log/local2-allloc[?12l[?25h[?25la.*      /var/log/local2-allloca[?12l[?25h[?25ll.*      /var/log/local2-alllocal[?12l[?25h[?25l2.* [1;66r[65;1H[1m[34m~                                                                                                                  [3;1H[?12l[?25h[?25l[m[66;1H1 more line; before #5  2 seconds ago[3;65r[3;1H[L[1;66r[3;1H:syslogtag, isequal, "appli1"[66;1H[K[3;1H[?12l[?25h[2;1H[?25l[2;65r[65;1H
[1;66r[65;1H[1m[34m~                                                                                                                  [2;1H[?12l[?25h[?25l[66;1H[m:[?12l[?25hw[?25l"/etc/rsyslog.d/appli1.conf" 4L, 108C written[2;1H[?12l[?25h[66;1H
